My bf quit his job last week, since he faints at least weekly, vomits 2-3 times a week, and gets these \"panic attacks\" every other day at least (we're currently on day 4 of a long storm). Second appointment was Tuesday. Doc decided to lower lyrica to 100mg (???) and prescribed Silexan, a lavender oil extract(?!?!?!) available from natural food stores. Not available to buy in my country. No pharmacist near us has heard of it. Doc still refuses to do anything else and outright refused ativan when my bf asked for it because it's \"not serious enough\". Next appointment is in over a month. Bf was on the floor half an hour ago and unable to get up. Where I'm stuck: We're stuck in a loop of \"well, he has a doctor, so go see him\" whenever we consult a nurse, ER, clinic, etc... and a doctor that isn't taking this seriously. We're in Canada (Quebec) with no family doctor and current doc and er won't refer to a neurologist. We've tried putting in a doctor change request but in a strained system it's not going through. I've reached out to work colleagues within mental health research and they can't help/shuttle him in anywhere. Bf is struggling with feeling suicidal/like a burden and I'm scared all the time
155.answer: I’m so sorry you and your boyfriend are going through this. What you’re describing is deeply concerning, and your instincts as a mental health researcher are valid. While panic attacks can present with a wide range of symptoms, the combination of neurological symptoms (e.g., loss of balance, slurred speech, rapid eye movements, fainting, memory loss, and prolonged episodes) raises red flags that this may not be purely psychiatric. The fact that these episodes last 3-6 hours and occur so frequently is also highly unusual for typical panic attacks. Here are some thoughts and suggestions:1. Neurological Evaluation is CrucialThe symptoms you’re describing (e.g., slurred speech, loss of balance, fainting, rapid eye movements, memory loss) could indicate a neurological condition. Some possibilities to consider include:Epilepsy or non-convulsive seizures: Some seizure types (e.g., complex partial seizures or absence seizures) can mimic panic attacks and cause memory loss, confusion, and autonomic symptoms like vomiting. An EEG might not always catch these if it wasn’t done during an episode.Vestibular disorders: Issues with the inner ear or balance system could explain the loss of balance and slurred speech.Migraine-associated vertigo or vestibular migraines: These can cause neurological symptoms without the typical headache.Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) or dysautonomia: These conditions can cause fainting, rapid heart rate, and anxiety-like symptoms.Structural brain abnormalities: While the MRI was clear, some conditions (e.g., small tumors, vascular issues) might not always show up on a standard scan.Metabolic or autoimmune conditions: Conditions like hypoglycemia, thyroid dysfunction, or autoimmune encephalitis can cause neurological and psychiatric symptoms.A neurologist would be best equipped to investigate these possibilities. The fact that the ER dismissed him after a normal MRI and EEG is frustrating but not uncommon. Neurological conditions can be tricky to diagnose, and further testing (e.g., a prolonged EEG, tilt table test, or lumbar puncture) might be needed.2. Advocate for a Neurologist ReferralSince your current doctor isn’t taking this seriously, you may need to escalate the situation. Here’s how:Document everything: Keep a detailed log of his symptoms, including dates, times, duration, and triggers. Note any patterns (e.g., relation to stress, food, alcohol, or posture changes).Push for a second opinion: If his psychiatrist refuses to refer him to a neurologist, try going back to the ER during an active episode. The ER might be more likely to take him seriously if they see him in the midst of an attack.Contact a patient advocacy organization: In Canada, organizations like the Canadian Patient Safety Institute or Health Quality Ontario might be able to help you navigate the system or escalate your concerns.Consider private healthcare: If you can afford it, seeing a neurologist privately (even across the border in the U.S.) might be worth exploring.3. Rule Out Medication Side EffectsLyrica (pregabalin) can cause dizziness, confusion, and balance issues, especially at higher doses. The fact that his symptoms worsened after starting Lyrica is worth noting. Seroquel (quetiapine) can also cause orthostatic hypotension (a drop in blood pressure upon standing), which might explain some of the fainting episodes.Discuss these side effects with his doctor or pharmacist. If the doctor is unwilling to adjust his medications, consider seeking a second opinion from another psychiatrist or primary care provider.4. Consider Other Medical CausesGiven his history of alcohol use and recent stress, it’s worth ruling out other medical conditions:Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome: This is a thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency often seen in people with alcohol use disorder. Symptoms include confusion, balance issues, and eye movement abnormalities.Electrolyte imbalances: Prolonged vomiting can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, which can cause neurological symptoms.Hypoglycemia: Low blood sugar can cause confusion, slurred speech, and fainting.A thorough blood workup (including thiamine, electrolytes, glucose, thyroid function, and liver function) might be helpful.5. Mental Health SupportWhile this may not be purely psychiatric, the stress of living with undiagnosed symptoms is undoubtedly taking a toll on his mental health. His suicidal thoughts and feelings of being a burden are serious and need to be addressed.Crisis support: If he’s feeling suicidal, please reach out to a crisis line (e.g., 1-833-456-4566 in Canada) or take him to the ER.Therapy: Even if his psychiatrist won’t refer him, look into community mental health programs or online therapy options (e.g., BetterHelp, Talkspace).6. Next StepsGo back to the ER during an episode: If he has another severe episode, take him to the ER and insist on a neurological evaluation. Seeing him in the midst of an attack might prompt them to take his symptoms more seriously.Seek a new doctor: Continue pushing for a doctor change. In the meantime, try reaching out to walk-in clinics or telemedicine services to see if another doctor will refer him to a neurologist.Consider a medical advocate: If you’re feeling overwhelmed, consider hiring a patient advocate or asking a trusted friend or family member to help you navigate the system.Final ThoughtsYour boyfriend is lucky to have you advocating for him. Trust your instincts—this doesn’t sound like typical panic attacks, and further investigation is warranted. Keep pushing for answers, and don’t hesitate to escalate your concerns if his current medical team isn’t taking this seriously. Wishing you both strength and clarity as you navigate this difficult situation.

156.question: My son- 2.5 year old M, 3 feet tall, 35 lbs, takes 1.5ml Keppra 2x/day- diagnosed with generalized epilepsy in December and taking keppra since then- had mri under sedation in Feb and found a significant Chiari malformation (normal cerebellar tonsils are 3-5 mm, his are 15)- they say the chiari and epilepsy are not related though it seems like quite a coincidence to me. Thoughts??
156.answer: I'm not a doctor, but I can provide some general information that might help you understand the situation better. It’s always important to discuss your concerns with your son’s healthcare team, as they have access to his full medical history and can provide personalized advice.Chiari Malformation and EpilepsyChiari malformation is a structural defect in the base of the skull and cerebellum, which can sometimes lead to neurological symptoms. In your son’s case, the cerebellar tonsils are significantly lower than normal (15 mm vs. the typical 3-5 mm), which is considered a significant Chiari malformation (likely Type I). This condition can sometimes cause symptoms like headaches, balance issues, or even seizures, but it is not typically associated with generalized epilepsy.Are They Related?The doctors may have concluded that the Chiari malformation and epilepsy are unrelated because:Generalized epilepsy typically arises from abnormal electrical activity across the entire brain, rather than from a structural issue like Chiari malformation.Chiari malformation-related seizures (if they occur) are usually focal and tied to brainstem or cerebellar compression, not generalized seizures.Your son’s epilepsy was diagnosed as generalized, which suggests a different underlying cause, possibly genetic or related to brain development.That said, it’s understandable why you might see this as a coincidence worth exploring further. Chiari malformation can sometimes cause symptoms that mimic or overlap with epilepsy, such as muscle stiffness, spasms, or even seizures due to brainstem compression. However, if your son’s MRI and EEG findings support generalized epilepsy as a separate diagnosis, the doctors may be confident in their assessment.Next StepsAsk for clarification: Request a detailed explanation from your son’s neurologist about why they believe the two conditions are unrelated. Ask if there’s any possibility of overlap or if further tests (e.g., a follow-up MRI or EEG) could provide more insight.Monitor symptoms: Keep a detailed log of your son’s seizures, including their frequency, duration, and any potential triggers. This can help the doctors determine if there’s any pattern that might suggest a connection to the Chiari malformation.Consider a second opinion: If you’re still unsure, seeking a second opinion from a pediatric neurologist or a specialist in Chiari malformation might provide additional clarity.Surgical evaluation: In some cases, significant Chiari malformation may require surgical intervention (e.g., decompression surgery) if it’s causing symptoms. Ask if this is something that should be considered for your son, even if it’s not directly related to the epilepsy.Final ThoughtsWhile it’s possible for Chiari malformation and epilepsy to coexist independently, your concern is valid, and it’s worth exploring whether there’s any connection in your son’s case. Keep advocating for your child, and don’t hesitate to ask questions until you feel confident in the care plan.

157.question: This is going to be a long post, I also copy pasted it from my previous post on a different forum which I used because I thought this forum was taken down. Im not sure if that's ok.I (m24) have had episodes of sudden double vision which lasts approximately 40 minutes each time for 5 years. I am responsive and coherent during episodes. They are usually a few grouped together within 2 weeks of each other and no more than 10 'episodes' a year.This is something I have seen many doctors, including neurologists, for ever since it began and have never gotten solid answers.Things ruled out by medical professionals and lab tests are: epilepsy  migraines   vertigo    brain masses  scar tissue in brain  eye diseases  blood sugar problems  blood pressure   medication levels Through my own observations by recording and testing things during episodes I have also found that it has no correlation with dehydration  eye appearance (pupil size, placement and no involuntary eye movement)  blood sugar  temperatures  foods or caffeine time of day   medications  body position (standing, sitting, laying down, walking)    eye fatigue smoking (happened both before I started smoking and after) finally realized I will start feeling slightly disoriented about 5-10 minutes before it starts. When the double vision starts, moving around promotes more dizziness but only because my eyes can't focus. If I am sitting down or keeping my head level there will still be feeling of mild disorientation and double vision but no dizziness. These episodes last almost exactly 40 minutes every time (I set a stopwatch when they start.) with the longest edging closer to an hour.  I started having peripheral neuropathy involving both arms and both legs early this year but after blood tests we found out I had severe vitamin D deficiency. After high doses of Vitamin D this completely went away and I was hoping the double vision would also go away (because most of the episodes happen between september and april, lower light months). But unfortunately it's still happening.Again I am left anxious and concerned because the episodes just came back. A notable episode happened recently when the double vision was significantly worse than ever before and went away when I used only one eye (it used to happen no matter which eye I looked through or if I used both.). It made the double vision go from a noticeable but slight 'distance' between the two versions I see, to double vision that showed stuff separate up to 3 inches apart. I don't drive so it's no danger to myself or others but when I'm walking it makes it hard to make out things like stoplights or to be able to look side to side to check for cars without feeling like I will fall. Just knowing it might start at any moment is so terrible.I have looked this up and talked to doctors about it so much over the past 5 years and I just want to know if there are any other reasons these might be happening or advice about what to do.I forgot to mention I did have a few minor concussions as a kid. 3 notable ones were when i broke my nose falling directly on my face with some confusion, the back of my head going through drywall and a hit against the back of my head where i may have blacked out for a second. No puking or memory loss after any and no need to see a doctor. and A benzo overdose a year before first episode with no short memory for 3 days (i was medically cleared afterwards and it caused no other issues) Thats why they were looking for possible scar tissue in my brain.The peripheral neuropathy mentioned came back. My vitamin D levels came back normal and my doctor checked my parathyroid hormone levels because of it and those also came back normal. She's suggesting neuro again but I probably won't schedule unless something gets worse or something new happens bc specialty appointments are expensive.
157.answer: I’m really sorry to hear about the ongoing challenges you’ve been facing with these episodes of double vision and the associated symptoms. It sounds like you’ve been through a lot of testing and consultations, and it’s frustrating not to have a clear answer yet. While I’m not a medical professional, I can offer some thoughts and suggestions based on what you’ve shared. It’s great that you’ve been so diligent in tracking your symptoms and ruling out many potential causes—this kind of detailed record-keeping can be incredibly helpful for doctors.Possible Considerations:Binocular Vision Dysfunction (BVD):BVD occurs when the eyes struggle to work together properly, leading to symptoms like double vision, dizziness, and disorientation. It can sometimes be triggered by stress, fatigue, or even minor misalignments in the eyes. A neuro-optometrist or specialist in binocular vision might be able to assess this further.Transient Ischemic Attacks (TIAs) or Vascular Issues:While TIAs are often associated with older adults, they can occur in younger people and cause temporary neurological symptoms like double vision. Given your history of concussions and the benzo overdose, it might be worth exploring whether there’s any vascular or blood flow issue affecting your brain. A neurologist could consider imaging studies like an MRA (magnetic resonance angiography) to rule this out.Post-Concussion Syndrome or Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI):Even minor concussions can sometimes lead to long-term effects, especially if you’ve had multiple head injuries. Post-concussion syndrome can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including vision problems, dizziness, and disorientation. A neurologist specializing in TBI might be able to provide more insight.Functional Neurological Disorder (FND):FND is a condition where the brain has trouble sending and receiving signals properly, leading to symptoms like double vision, dizziness, and disorientation. It’s often diagnosed after other conditions are ruled out, and it can be triggered by stress, trauma, or other factors. A neurologist familiar with FND might be able to evaluate this possibility.Autoimmune or Inflammatory Conditions:Conditions like multiple sclerosis (MS) or other autoimmune disorders can cause episodes of double vision and neurological symptoms. While you’ve had imaging done, it might be worth revisiting this possibility if new symptoms arise or if your episodes change in nature.Vestibular Migraines or Atypical Migraines:While migraines have been ruled out, vestibular migraines can sometimes present without headache and cause symptoms like double vision, dizziness, and disorientation. These can be tricky to diagnose and might require a specialist in headache disorders.Nutritional or Metabolic Factors:Since you’ve had issues with vitamin D deficiency and peripheral neuropathy, it might be worth exploring other nutritional deficiencies (e.g., B vitamins, magnesium) or metabolic issues that could affect nerve function and vision.Next Steps:Keep a Detailed Symptom Diary: Continue tracking your episodes, including any potential triggers, the duration, and any new or changing symptoms. This can help identify patterns and provide valuable information for your doctors.Consider a Second Opinion: If you haven’t already, seeking a second opinion from a different neurologist or a specialist in neuro-ophthalmology might provide new insights.Neuro-Ophthalmology Evaluation: A neuro-ophthalmologist specializes in vision problems related to the nervous system and might be able to offer a more targeted assessment.Explore Stress or Anxiety Management: Stress and anxiety can sometimes exacerbate neurological symptoms. While this isn’t a direct cause, managing stress might help reduce the frequency or severity of episodes.Discuss Cost Concerns with Your Doctor: If cost is a barrier to seeing a specialist, let your primary care doctor know. They might be able to help prioritize tests or refer you to a clinic with sliding-scale fees.Final Thoughts:It’s understandable to feel anxious and frustrated when dealing with unexplained symptoms, especially over such a long period. While it’s good that your symptoms haven’t worsened significantly, the recent change in the severity of your double vision is concerning and warrants further investigation. Don’t hesitate to advocate for yourself and seek additional evaluations if needed.I hope you’re able to find some answers and relief soon. Take care, and feel free to reach out if you need further support or suggestions.

Is there a cage/walker product that allows us to take him on walks and would catch him via a harness should he fall? 158.answer: I'm sorry to hear about your brother's condition, and it's great that you're looking for ways to support him. While I'm not aware of a specific product that matches your exact description, there are a few options and adaptations that might help you achieve your goal safely:Gait Trainer or Support Walker with Harness:Some medical walkers or gait trainers are designed for individuals with mobility challenges and include harness systems to prevent falls. Look for products like the Rifton Pacer Gait Trainer or Kaye Posture Walker, which can be customized with harnesses and supports. For outdoor use, you might consider a rollator walker with a harness attachment, though you may need to consult with a medical equipment specialist to ensure it can handle sudden falls.Custom Solutions:If off-the-shelf products don't meet your needs, you might consider working with a physical therapist or occupational therapist to design a custom solution. 159.question: 26f. 122lbs, 5'2\". Never smoker, rare drinker. On medication (trokendi, fycompa, Yaz, pristiq, creon, Cymbalta, b12 injections, pepsid, abilify). History of epilepsy, migraines, chronic pancreatitis status post tp/ait.Went to ED for abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting that was unremitting for weeks. Had abdominal CT that found incidental liver lesions. Followed up with an MRI with contrast. The below are the findings in my liver. Hpw should I interpret? Is it something to worry about?\"There are multiple (at least 7) arterially enhancing lesions in both lobes of liver, which are hyperintense on T2 and without internal fat. The dominant lesion measures 1.8 cm and seen in segment 6 of the right lobe (29:67). A few other prominent lesions include 6 mm segment 6 (29:47), 8 mm segment 5 (29:40), and 3 mm segment 2 (29:30). No definite washout however the lesions appear to enhance less then background vessels on delayed phases, arguing against hemangioma.Multiple arterially enhancing lesions in both lobes of liver, largest measuring up to 1.8 cm in segment 6 of the right lobe. Imaging features suggest adenoma with the differential including focal nodular hyperplasia.\
159.answer: The MRI findings describe multiple arterially enhancing lesions in your liver, with the largest measuring 1.8 cm. The imaging features suggest hepatic adenoma as the most likely diagnosis, with focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) as another possibility. Here's how to interpret this:Key Findings:Arterially enhancing lesions: These lesions "light up" during the arterial phase of contrast imaging, which is typical of certain liver tumors like adenomas or FNH.Hyperintense on T2: This means the lesions appear bright on T2-weighted MRI images, which is consistent with adenomas or FNH.No internal fat: This rules out certain other liver lesions, such as some types of adenomas that contain fat.No definite washout: Washout is a feature often seen in malignant lesions like hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Its absence is reassuring.Enhance less than background vessels on delayed phases: This argues against hemangioma, a common benign liver lesion.Likely Diagnosis:Hepatic adenoma: A benign liver tumor that is more common in women, especially those on hormonal medications (like Yaz, which you are taking). Adenomas can sometimes grow or bleed, so they need monitoring.Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH): Another benign liver lesion that is usually asymptomatic and does not require treatment.Should You Worry?These lesions are likely benign, but they need further evaluation and monitoring because:Hepatic adenomas can rarely grow, bleed, or (very rarely) transform into malignancy, especially if they are larger than 5 cm. Yours are smaller, which is reassuring.Your history of chronic pancreatitis and medications (like hormonal birth control) may influence the behavior of these lesions.Next Steps:Consult a hepatologist or gastroenterologist: They can help interpret these findings in the context of your medical history and medications.Consider stopping hormonal medications: If these lesions are adenomas, Yaz (a hormonal birth control) may need to be discontinued, as it can promote their growth.Follow-up imaging: Repeat imaging (e.g., MRI or ultrasound) in 3-6 months to monitor for changes in size or appearance of the lesions.Biopsy (if needed): If the diagnosis remains unclear or if the lesions grow, a biopsy may be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.Summary:The findings are likely benign (adenoma or FNH), but they require follow-up and possibly adjustments to your medications. This is not an emergency, but it is important to address it with your healthcare provider to ensure proper management.

160.question: Hello. This is about my wife who is 19F. Non smoker. Non vaper. No medical issues. No history of epilepsy in her family. I would like to highlight main parts of this inquiry. Not going into too much detail unless required by someone.My wife (19) first time pregnant had an emergency C section at 36 weeks due to breech. Baby passed away. She was fine. Had some headaches and after 6 days at home she felt blurry vision and after about 20 mins got her first seizure ever. Got 2nd one in the ambulance and after reaching hospital had 3 more.In the hospital they performed another spinal tap for her CSF (Lumbar puncture) and MRI. All tests etc were good. MRI suggested some activity in the front part of her brain. But doctors couldn't pinpoint anything. They concluded that it must have happened due to her previous spinal anesthesia for c section which is rare but not impossible.She was discharged 12 days later with Phenytoin medicine for epilepsy. 300mg per day (3 tablets all together) for 3 months. It has been a month and half (or less) and she had no seizure but some strange observations I had about her: Very sensitive to light especially when very sleepy or waking up.She had blurry vision again but partially and in one eye. One day she had in both eyes.e become a deep sleeper and it becomes really hard to wake her up. She would sleep for about 7 to 9 hours and wake up only if we woke her up. When I discussed these observations with the doctor he told me to decrease dosage to 200mg per day. Almost 2 weeks now since lowering her dosage. She has developed this strange itching all over her body that prevents her from sleeping since 3 to 5 days. She also felt her hand vibrate or shake for 2 to 3 secs while sleeping. oday she said that she felt her whole right side of the body vibrate a little and after that her right arm. She seems normal for the most part. No slurred speech, just that she forgot some of the things before seizures and also her journey from home to hospital. So is she at risk of getting seizures again? I am too damn afraid. Even when she itches the whole bed vibrates the same way it did when she had her seizure and this thing keeps me on my toes at all times. I also read that the itching can be due to some neurological issues and I think it might be Multiple sclerosis??
160.answer: I'm very sorry to hear about your wife's experience and the loss of your baby. This is an incredibly difficult situation, and it's understandable that you're concerned about her health. Based on what you've described, here are some key points and considerations:Key Points:Seizures Post-C-Section:Your wife had her first-ever seizures shortly after a C-section, which were potentially linked to the spinal anesthesia (a rare complication known as post-dural puncture headache or intracranial hypotension). However, the MRI showed some activity in the front part of her brain, which is unusual and warrants further monitoring.Medication (Phenytoin):She was prescribed Phenytoin, an anti-epileptic drug, to prevent further seizures. While it seems to be working (no seizures in over a month), she is experiencing side effects like sensitivity to light, blurry vision, deep sleep, and now itching and vibrations.Recent Symptoms:Itching: This could be a side effect of Phenytoin, as itching (pruritus) is a known adverse reaction. However, it could also be due to other causes, such as hormonal changes post-pregnancy, stress, or even a neurological issue.Vibrations/Shaking: These sensations could be related to her nervous system, possibly a side effect of the medication or a sign of neurological activity (e.g., focal seizures or nerve irritation).Memory Loss: The memory gaps around the time of the seizures are not uncommon and are often due to the brain's disruption during the seizure activity.Risk of Seizures:The fact that she hasn't had a seizure in over a month is a positive sign. However, the recent symptoms (itching, vibrations) could indicate that her brain is still in a sensitive state. Lowering the Phenytoin dosage might have reduced some side effects but could also increase the risk of breakthrough seizures.Concerns and Next Steps:Phenytoin Side Effects:Phenytoin can cause a range of side effects, including drowsiness, blurred vision, and itching. The vibrations/shaking could also be related to the medication or her underlying neurological condition. Discuss these symptoms with her neurologist to determine if an alternative medication (e.g., Levetiracetam) might be better tolerated.Neurological Evaluation:The itching and vibrations could be neurological in origin. While Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a possibility, it is less likely given her age and lack of other typical MS symptoms (e.g., muscle weakness, coordination issues). However, a follow-up with a neurologist is crucial to rule out other conditions like postpartum cerebral angiopathy, small seizures (focal seizures), or nerve irritation.Risk of Seizures:She is still at risk of seizures, especially since the dosage of Phenytoin was reduced. The vibrations/shaking could be a warning sign of focal seizures or increased brain activity. Keep a close eye on her and seek immediate medical attention if she experiences any unusual movements, loss of awareness, or worsening symptoms.Postpartum Hormonal Changes:Pregnancy and childbirth can cause significant hormonal shifts, which may contribute to her symptoms (e.g., itching, sleep disturbances). A consultation with an endocrinologist or her OB/GYN might help rule out hormonal imbalances.Psychological Support:The trauma of losing a baby and experiencing seizures can have a profound psychological impact. Consider seeking counseling or therapy for her (and yourself) to help process these events.Immediate Actions:Consult Her Neurologist: Share the new symptoms (itching, vibrations, shaking) and discuss whether further tests (e.g., EEG, repeat MRI) are needed.Monitor Closely: Keep a diary of her symptoms, including when they occur and how long they last. This will help her doctors identify patterns or triggers.Emergency Plan: If she experiences a seizure, ensure you know what to do (e.g., keep her safe, time the seizure, call for help if it lasts more than 5 minutes).Final Thoughts:Your wife's situation is complex, and it's important to address both the physical and emotional aspects of her recovery. While the risk of seizures remains, her symptoms could also be related to medication side effects or postpartum changes. Stay in close contact with her healthcare team and advocate for thorough follow-up care. You're doing a great job supporting her, but don't forget to take care of yourself too.

161.question: Every so often I get these really weird sensations that feel somewhat neurological that I haven't a clue what they are since they seem so different from anything else I know of. I've been getting them occasionally for over a year now. 25F. I just had one now and it leaves me in such a weird state of mind afterwards.I feel somewhat floaty and dizzy currently, so please forgive me if this isn't constructed well.It begins as a tingling sensation? Like a shiver. That flushes through me. And I feel some kind of emotion that I can't describe, like dread or deja vu or some kind of combination of the two. I become hyperaware of my sorroundings, like reality has become more real? It's very abstract and weird, I know. 161.answer: What you're describing sounds like a complex and unusual experience, and while I’m not a medical professional, I can offer some insights and suggestions that might help you better understand or address this. The sensations you’re experiencing—tingling, emotional shifts (like dread or déjà vu), hyperawareness, dizziness, and a light headache—could potentially be related to a few different neurological or physiological phenomena. Here are some possibilities to consider:1. Focal Seizures or Simple Partial SeizuresThe sensations you describe (tingling, emotional shifts, hyperawareness, and déjà vu) are sometimes associated with focal seizures (also called partial seizures). These seizures originate in a specific part of the brain and don’t always involve loss of consciousness or convulsions.The "floaty" or dizzy feeling afterward, along with the headache, could be part of the post-ictal phase (the recovery period after a seizure).Focal seizures can be caused by various factors, including stress, sleep deprivation, or underlying neurological conditions.What to do: If this hasn’t been evaluated yet, it might be worth discussing with a neurologist. They may recommend an EEG (electroencephalogram) to check for abnormal brain activity.2. Migraine Aura or Silent MigraineWhile you mentioned that this feels different from your migraines with visual aura, some migraine variants (like silent migraines or migraine aura without headache) can cause neurological symptoms without the typical headache.Symptoms like tingling, dizziness, and altered perception of reality can sometimes be part of a migraine aura.What to do: Keep a detailed journal of these episodes, including triggers (e.g., stress, diet, sleep patterns) and symptoms. Share this with a doctor to see if migraines could be a factor.3. Anxiety or Panic AttacksThe emotional component (dread, hyperawareness) and physical sensations (tingling, dizziness) could also be related to anxiety or panic attacks. These episodes can sometimes feel very physical and overwhelming, even if there’s no obvious emotional trigger.The "floaty" feeling afterward might be related to the body’s response to a surge of adrenaline.What to do: If you suspect anxiety could be a factor, consider speaking with a mental health professional. They can help you explore coping strategies or determine if anxiety is contributing to these episodes.4. Dysautonomia or Autonomic DysfunctionConditions like dysautonomia (e.g., POTS—postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome) can cause dizziness, tingling, and altered perception due to issues with the autonomic nervous system.These symptoms can sometimes be triggered by changes in posture, stress, or dehydration.What to do: If you frequently experience dizziness or "floaty" sensations, it might be worth checking your blood pressure and heart rate during these episodes. A doctor can evaluate for autonomic dysfunction.5. Sensory Processing or DissociationThe hyperawareness and altered perception of reality could be related to dissociation or a heightened sensory processing state. This can sometimes occur during stress, fatigue, or as part of conditions like depersonalization-derealization disorder.The tingling and emotional shifts might be part of your body’s response to stress or overwhelm.What to do: If dissociation feels like a possibility, a therapist or psychologist can help you explore this further.6. Other ConsiderationsHormonal fluctuations: Hormonal changes (e.g., related to your menstrual cycle) can sometimes cause neurological or sensory symptoms.Nutritional deficiencies: Low levels of vitamins like B12 or magnesium can cause tingling, dizziness, and neurological symptoms.Vestibular issues: Problems with the inner ear or balance system could contribute to dizziness and altered perception.Next Steps:Keep a Symptom Journal: Record details of each episode, including:What you were doing before it happened.How long it lasted.Specific symptoms (physical and emotional).Any potential triggers (e.g., stress, lack of sleep, diet).Consult a Doctor: Start with your primary care physician, who may refer you to a neurologist or other specialist. 162.answer: I'm really sorry to hear about the challenges you've been facing with your epilepsy and mental health. These could be complicating factors in your treatment.EEG Results: Your EEGs show intermittent slowing in the fronto-temporal regions but no clear epileptiform abnormalities. The most recent EEG (April 2022) was normal.Why Things Might Have Gone Downhill:Medication Changes: Stopping or switching antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) can sometimes destabilize seizure control, especially if the transition isn’t managed carefully. In your case, the abrupt switch from Keppra to a very low dose of Lamotrigine (25mg) may have triggered breakthrough seizures.Sleep Deprivation: You mentioned that sleep deprivation is a major trigger for your myoclonic seizures. The night you had only 2 hours of sleep before the major seizure in September 2022 is a clear example of this. Poor sleep hygiene or stress could be contributing to ongoing issues.Inadequate Medication Dosing: The initial dose of Lamotrigine (25mg) was likely too low to provide adequate seizure control. Lamotrigine typically requires gradual titration to therapeutic doses (often 100-200mg/day or higher). Your current dose of 100mg Lamotrigine + 1g Keppra might still not be optimal for controlling myoclonic seizures.Underlying Epilepsy Type: Your history of myoclonic seizures and tonic-clonic seizures suggests you might have a generalized epilepsy syndrome, such as Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME). JME is highly sensitive to sleep deprivation and often requires lifelong treatment with specific AEDs like Valproate, Lamotrigine, or Levetiracetam (Keppra).Mental Health and Stress: Your mental health struggles could be exacerbating your epilepsy. Stress, anxiety, and depression are known seizure triggers and can also affect sleep quality, creating a vicious cycle.EEG Interpretation:Fronto-Temporal Slowing: This suggests some dysfunction in these brain regions, which could be related to your epilepsy. However, the absence of clear epileptiform discharges (spikes or sharp waves) doesn’t rule out epilepsy, especially in generalized epilepsy syndromes.Normal EEG (April 2022): A normal EEG doesn’t exclude epilepsy, as EEGs can be normal between seizures, especially in generalized epilepsy.What You Can Do:Seek a Second Opinion: Consider consulting an epileptologist (a neurologist specializing in epilepsy) to review your case. They might have more experience with complex epilepsy syndromes and medication management.Optimize Medication: Your current regimen might need adjustment. For example:Lamotrigine: This is often effective for myoclonic seizures but requires careful titration. You might need a higher dose.Keppra: 1g twice daily is a standard dose, but some people need higher doses for full control.Clobazam: This is a good rescue medication, but if you’re using it frequently, it might indicate that your baseline treatment isn’t adequate.Address Sleep Issues: Prioritize good sleep hygiene. If you’re struggling with insomnia or poor sleep, consider discussing this with your doctor. They might recommend a sleep study or adjustments to your routine.Mental Health Support: Addressing your mental health is crucial. Therapy (e.g., CBT, DBT) and possibly medication for anxiety/depression could help reduce stress and improve seizure control.Keep a Seizure Diary: Track your seizures, triggers (e.g., sleep deprivation, stress), and medication changes. 163.answer: I'm really sorry to hear you're experiencing this—it sounds incredibly distressing and confusing. While I’m not a doctor, the symptoms you’re describing (one-sided numbness, difficulty communicating, severe headaches, light/sound sensitivity, and temporary vision loss) could potentially align with a neurological condition. Here are a few possibilities that might be worth exploring with a healthcare professional:1. Migraine with Aura (Hemiplegic Migraine)What it is: A type of migraine that can cause one-sided numbness, weakness, and sensory disturbances (like the "line down the middle" you described). It can also involve difficulty speaking, visual disturbances, and severe headaches.Why it fits: Your symptoms (numbness, headache, light/sound sensitivity, vision loss) are consistent with migraine aura. Hemiplegic migraines are a rare subtype that can mimic stroke-like symptoms.Next steps: Keep a detailed journal of your episodes (triggers, duration, symptoms) and consult a neurologist. They may consider migraine-specific treatments or preventive medications.2. Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) or Mini-StrokeWhat it is: A temporary disruption of blood flow to the brain, causing stroke-like symptoms that resolve within hours.Why it fits: One-sided numbness, speech difficulties, and vision loss can occur during a TIA. However, TIAs are less likely to recur so frequently without underlying risk factors (e.g., heart conditions, blood clotting disorders).Next steps: A neurologist might investigate vascular causes, such as blood clots or heart abnormalities, through imaging (e.g., MRI, CT scan) or blood tests.3. Functional Neurological Disorder (FND)What it is: A condition where the brain has trouble sending and receiving signals properly, leading to physical symptoms (e.g., numbness, weakness, speech issues) without structural damage.Why it fits: FND can cause episodic symptoms like yours, especially in individuals with a history of anxiety or other mental health conditions. Stress or emotional triggers might play a role.Next steps: A neurologist or psychologist specializing in FND could help explore this possibility. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or physical therapy might be recommended.4. Epilepsy (Focal Seizures)What it is: Seizures that originate in one part of the brain, causing localized symptoms like numbness, speech difficulties, or sensory changes.Why it fits: Focal seizures can cause one-sided symptoms and temporary loss of function. The post-episode headache and sensitivity to light/sound could be part of a post-ictal state.Next steps: An EEG (electroencephalogram) might help detect abnormal brain activity. A neurologist could evaluate whether anticonvulsant medications are appropriate.5. Multiple Sclerosis (MS) or Other Demyelinating ConditionsWhat it is: A condition where the immune system attacks the protective covering of nerves, causing neurological symptoms.Why it fits: MS can cause episodes of numbness, weakness, and sensory disturbances. However, MS typically involves other symptoms (e.g., balance issues, fatigue) and is less likely to present so episodically without progression.Next steps: A neurologist might consider an MRI to look for signs of demyelination.6. Complex Migraine or Stroke MimicsWhat it is: Some conditions, like vasospasm or cerebral vasculitis, can mimic stroke or migraine symptoms.Why it fits: These conditions can cause temporary neurological deficits and headaches.Next steps: A neurologist might investigate blood vessel abnormalities or autoimmune conditions.What You Can Do Now:See a Neurologist: A specialist can evaluate your symptoms in detail and order appropriate tests (e.g., MRI, EEG, blood work).Keep a Symptom Journal: Track when episodes occur, how long they last, potential triggers (stress, diet, sleep, etc.), and all symptoms.Consider a Second Opinion: If your previous tests were inconclusive, a fresh evaluation might help.Explore Migraine Management: Even if it’s not migraines, some migraine treatments (e.g., magnesium, riboflavin, or prescription preventives) might help.Your symptoms are significant and deserve thorough investigation. While it’s frustrating not to have answers yet, a neurologist with expertise in episodic neurological conditions is your best bet for getting to the bottom of this. Let me know if you’d like help preparing for a doctor’s appointment or finding resources!

neurological and psychological effects.Autonomic Dysfunction: Symptoms like trembling, restricted circulation, and sensory sensitivity could point to dysautonomia (e.g., POTS or other autonomic nervous system issues).Anxiety or Panic Disorders: The panic attacks, depersonalization, and sensory overload might be linked to an anxiety disorder or heightened stress response.Histamine Intolerance or Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS): These conditions can cause a wide range of symptoms, including neurological, gastrointestinal, and psychological issues, often triggered by food.Next Steps:Consult a Specialist:Neurologist: To rule out or confirm migraine variants, seizures, or other neurological conditions.Gastroenterologist: To investigate potential food intolerances, IBS, or 168.question: So I was diagnosed with Epilepsy last August and put on Keppra 1000mg twice a day. I did not like how it made me feel, so they moved it to once a day. 168.answer: I'm sorry to hear about your diagnosis and the challenges you're facing with Keppra. It's important to work closely with your healthcare provider to manage your epilepsy and medication side effects, but I can offer some general advice that might help.1. Side Effects of KeppraFeeling foggy or "drunk" is a relatively common side effect of Keppra (levetiracetam), especially when starting the medication or adjusting the dose. Some people also report fatigue, dizziness, or mood changes.These side effects may improve over time as your body adjusts to the medication, but if they persist or worsen, it’s important to discuss this with your doctor.2. Timing of DosesTaking Keppra once a day might not be ideal for maintaining stable blood levels of the medication, which could contribute to side effects or reduced effectiveness. Typically, Keppra is prescribed twice a day to keep levels consistent.If you’re feeling foggy, consider splitting the dose back to 500mg twice a day (if your doctor agrees) to see if it helps reduce the side effects.3. Taking Keppra with FoodKeppra can be taken with or without food, but taking it with food might help reduce stomach upset or other side effects for some people.If you’re feeling foggy after taking it, try taking it with a meal or snack to see if that helps.4. Time of DayIf drowsiness or fogginess is an issue, consider taking your dose before bed. This might help you sleep through some of the side effects.If you’re taking it twice a day, you could take one dose in the morning with breakfast and the other at bedtime.5. Hydration and LifestyleStaying well-hydrated and maintaining a consistent sleep schedule can help reduce side effects.Avoid alcohol, as it can worsen drowsiness and interact with Keppra.6. Discuss Alternatives with Your DoctorIf Keppra continues to cause significant side effects, there are other anti-seizure medications your doctor might consider, such as lamotrigine, valproate, or brivaracetam (a newer medication similar to Keppra but with potentially fewer side effects).Never stop or adjust your medication without consulting your doctor, as this could increase the risk of seizures.7. Monitor and ReportKeep a journal of your symptoms, including when you take your medication, how you feel, and any side effects. This can help your doctor tailor your treatment plan.Next Steps:Talk to your neurologist about your side effects and ask if adjusting the dose or timing could help.Consider asking about alternative medications if Keppra continues to be problematic.Make sure your doctor is aware of your Motrin use, as it’s important to monitor for any potential interactions (though Keppra and Motrin generally don’t interact significantly).It’s great that you’re being proactive about managing your health. Keep working with your healthcare team to find the best balance between controlling your seizures and minimizing side effects.

169.question: Age - 30   Sex - male    Height - 5'8\"-174 cm    Weight - 60 kgs.    Duration of complaint - 3 years    Location - Soft palate    Any existing relevant medical issues - Subjective Tinnitus caused by olanzapine and an MRI scan   Current medications - Cinolazepam for sleep, Mysoline for the myoclonus. Is palatal myoclonus treatable?
169.answer: Palatal myoclonus (PM) is a rare condition characterized by rhythmic, involuntary contractions of the soft palate. It can be classified into two types:Essential Palatal Myoclonus: Idiopathic (no clear cause) and often associated with an audible "clicking" sound due to the movement of the Eustachian tube.Symptomatic Palatal Myoclonus: Caused by underlying neurological conditions, such as brainstem lesions, multiple sclerosis, or trauma.Given your history of subjective tinnitus, olanzapine use, and myoclonus, it’s possible that your palatal myoclonus could be related to your neurological or medication history. Here’s an overview of treatment options:Treatment Options for Palatal Myoclonus:Medications:Clonazepam or other benzodiazepines may help reduce symptoms.Anticonvulsants like carbamazepine or gabapentin are sometimes used.Botulinum Toxin (Botox) Injections: These can be targeted to the soft palate muscles to reduce contractions. This is often considered when medications fail.Address Underlying Causes:If the myoclonus is linked to olanzapine or other medications, adjusting or discontinuing the drug (under medical supervision) may help.Treating any underlying neurological conditions (e.g., lesions detected on MRI) is crucial.Lifestyle and Supportive Measures:Stress management, as stress can exacerbate symptoms.Speech therapy or biofeedback may help in some cases.Surgical Options:In severe, refractory cases, surgical interventions like tensor veli palatini muscle sectioning may be considered, but this is rare.Next Steps:Consult a Neurologist: A specialist can reassess your condition, review your MRI findings, and determine if there’s an underlying cause for the palatal myoclonus.Medication Review: Discuss with your doctor whether olanzapine or other medications could be contributing to your symptoms.Consider Botox: If medications are ineffective, Botox injections may be a viable option.Palatal myoclonus can be challenging to treat, but many patients find relief with a combination of medications, Botox, and addressing underlying causes. Work closely with your healthcare provider to tailor a treatment plan to your specific needs.

170.question: Hi there. I was hoping someone could give me some input on an MRI view. I have access to the MRI so if anyone wants another image, I can view it. This is my most recent MRI, Jan 2021. 170.answer: I'm not a doctor, but I can provide some general information and suggestions based on what you've shared. Your case is complex and involves multiple systems (neurological, hematological, and possibly endocrine), so it’s important to work closely with specialists who can coordinate your care. Here are some thoughts and considerations:1. Cerebral Venous Sinus Thrombosis (CVST)Your history of CVST in 2019 is significant, especially given your Factor V Leiden mutation, which increases your risk of blood clots. The CVST could have caused lasting effects on your brain, including the development of epilepsy and potential changes in blood flow or pressure in the brain.The fact that your migraines improved after starting Eliquis suggests that the CVST may have been contributing to your migraine symptoms. However, the ongoing neurological symptoms (e.g., seizures, vision changes, temperature dysregulation) may indicate residual effects or other underlying issues.2. Epilepsy and SeizuresYour complex partial seizures originating in the right temporal lobe could be related to the CVST or other structural changes in your brain. Temporal lobe epilepsy can cause symptoms like déjà vu, zoning out, and speech disturbances (e.g., stuttering or repeating words).Keppra is a common antiseizure medication, but if your seizures are not fully controlled, your neurologist may consider other options. Since Zonisamide caused severe side effects, other medications like Lamotrigine or Lacosamide might be alternatives, but this would need to be discussed with your neurologist.3. Vision ChangesThe peripheral vision loss in your right eye could be related to the CVST or increased intracranial pressure at the time of the clot. It could also be unrelated (e.g., an optic nerve issue). A neuro-ophthalmologist might be helpful to evaluate this further.4. Temperature Dysregulation and Sleep IssuesTemperature regulation issues, sleep paralysis, hallucinations, and exploding head syndrome could be related to dysfunction in the hypothalamus or brainstem, which regulate sleep and autonomic functions. These symptoms might also be linked to your epilepsy or the aftereffects of the CVST.A sleep study (polysomnography) might help rule out other sleep disorders, and an endocrinologist could evaluate your autonomic nervous system and hypothalamic function.5. Weight Gain and Hormonal FactorsThe weight gain since your CVST could be due to multiple factors, including reduced activity, medications (e.g., Keppra, propranolol), or hormonal changes. It might be worth checking thyroid function, cortisol levels, and other hormonal markers to rule out endocrine causes.6. Next StepsAdvanced Imaging: Since you have access to your MRIs, a neuroradiologist or a specialist at a center like Cornell could review them in detail to look for subtle changes or abnormalities that might explain your symptoms.Comprehensive Neurological Evaluation: A tertiary care center (e.g., Cornell, Mayo Clinic, Johns Hopkins) would be ideal for coordinating care between neurology, hematology, endocrinology, and possibly psychiatry.Autonomic Testing: Given your temperature dysregulation and fainting episodes, autonomic testing (e.g., tilt table test) might be helpful.Genetic Counseling: Since you have Factor V Leiden, genetic counseling could provide more insight into your clotting risk and whether other genetic factors might be contributing to your symptoms.7. Covid ConcernsMany major medical centers are taking extensive precautions for in-person visits, and some offer telehealth consultations for initial evaluations. You could start with a virtual visit to discuss your case and determine the best next steps.8. Lifestyle and Symptom ManagementSleep Hygiene: Since sleep is a major issue, working with a sleep specialist or therapist to address your fear of sleep paralysis and improve sleep habits might help.Stress Management: Given the potential role of stress in exacerbating your symptoms, mindfulness, therapy, or relaxation techniques could be beneficial.Medication Review: Regularly review your medications with your doctors to ensure they’re not contributing to your symptoms (e.g., propranolol can sometimes cause fatigue or temperature sensitivity).Final ThoughtsYour case is complex and likely requires a multidisciplinary approach. While it’s understandable to want to avoid medical visits during Covid, your symptoms (e.g., seizures, vision changes, autonomic dysfunction) warrant a thorough evaluation. Starting with a virtual consultation at a major medical center could help you plan the next steps safely.If you’d like, you can share specific MRI images (e.g., T1-weighted, T2-weighted, FLAIR, or contrast-enhanced views) for a more detailed look, but a neuroradiologist would be the best person to interpret them in the context of your clinical history.Let me know if you have further questions or need clarification!

171.question: This last year at the ripe age of 32 I developed a myriad of health complications. Primarily nuerological comlications such as myoclonus, seizures, and a serious case of insomnia. Thankfully I am improving now. I was in excellent former health and this came on like wildfire. For 6 months I was in and out of hospitals. I had 6 MRIs done, 4 lumbar punctures, and 7 CT scans in the span of 6 months. The majority of the diagnostics were of low clinical yield and I was empirically treated for autoimmune conditions & epilepsy. I often feel that the excessive imaging(CT) only added insult to injury. I know this is already said and done and there's nothing I can do about it now, but im hoping maybe someone with a bit of knowledge and insight on the subject could ease my nerves about cancer risk etc. Below are the scans preformed and parameters that were made available to me. Where do I stand I'm comparison to radiation workers, patients treated with radiation therapy or gamma procedures, pilots, surviovors of eratic radiation exposure etc. I want to put these worries to rest and move forward with my life. Yes it's a simple as nothing I can do now but move forward and enjoy life. I'm just hoping to hear some people who may have gone through it and shared these worries that your all ok, or for someone with a background and focus in radiation(be it medicine, physics, engineering, etc)to tell me my worries are irrational. CT scans August 16th - Head scan Total Exam DLP: 1005.29 September 22nd - Head scan Total Exam DLP: 799 September 23rd - Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis Total Exam DLP: 652 September 25th - Head scan Total Exam DLP: 763 November 15th - Chest/abdomen/pelvis W contrast Total Exam DLP: 1291.11 CONTRAST: 80 mL of Iohexol Inj 80 mL November 18th - Full body PET scan Total Exam DLP: A fuck load December 15th - Head scan Total Exam DLP: 881.17
171.answer: First, I’m sorry to hear about the health challenges you’ve faced over the past year, but I’m glad to hear you’re improving. It’s completely understandable to feel concerned about the radiation exposure from the numerous imaging studies you underwent. Let’s break this down and address your concerns in a clear, evidence-based way.Understanding Radiation Exposure from CT ScansCT scans use ionizing radiation, which can increase the risk of cancer over time. However, the risk is generally small and must be weighed against the benefits of diagnosing and treating serious medical conditions. The amount of radiation is measured in millisieverts (mSv), and the Dose-Length Product (DLP) you provided can be converted to mSv using a conversion factor specific to the body region scanned.Here’s a rough estimate of the radiation exposure for each of your scans:Head CT scans (August 16th, September 22nd, September 25th, December 15th):Conversion factor for head CT: ~0.0021 mSv/(mGy·cm)Estimated effective dose per scan: ~1.5–2.1 mSvTotal for 4 head CTs: ~6–8.4 mSvChest/Abdomen/Pelvis CT scans (September 23rd, November 15th):Conversion factor for body CT: ~0.015 mSv/(mGy·cm)Estimated effective dose per scan: ~9.8–19.4 mSvTotal for 2 body CTs: ~19.6–38.8 mSvPET scan (November 18th):PET scans typically deliver ~7–10 mSv of radiation.Estimated effective dose: ~7–10 mSvTotal Estimated Radiation ExposureAdding these up, your total estimated radiation exposure over the 6 months is approximately 32–57 mSv. This is a cumulative dose from all your scans.Comparing Your Exposure to Other GroupsRadiation Workers: The annual occupational limit for radiation workers is 50 mSv/year, with a 5-year average of 20 mSv/year. Your exposure is within this range but concentrated in a short period.Pilots and Flight Crew: They are exposed to ~3–6 mSv/year from cosmic radiation. Your exposure is higher but still within the range of what some frequent flyers or pilots might experience over a decade.Radiation Therapy Patients: Patients undergoing radiation therapy for cancer receive thousands of mSv to targeted areas, far exceeding your exposure.Atomic Bomb Survivors: Survivors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki who received 50–100 mSv showed a slight increase in cancer risk over their lifetimes, but this is a different type of exposure (acute, whole-body).Cancer Risk from Your ExposureThe risk of cancer from radiation is typically estimated using a linear no-threshold model, which assumes that even small doses of radiation carry some risk. However, the risk is very small at the doses you received. For example:A cumulative dose of 100 mSv is associated with a ~1% increased lifetime risk of cancer. Your exposure is roughly half of this, so the additional risk is likely <1%.For comparison, the baseline lifetime risk of cancer in the general population is ~40%, so your exposure adds a very small increment to this.Key Points to Reassure YouYour exposure is not extreme: While you had multiple scans, your total dose is within the range of what some radiation workers or frequent flyers might experience over years.No immediate harm: The risks from radiation are long-term and probabilistic, not deterministic (i.e., they don’t guarantee harm).Benefits outweighed risks: The scans were necessary to diagnose and manage your serious neurological symptoms. The information gained likely justified the radiation exposure.No evidence of harm at these doses: Studies of populations exposed to similar doses (e.g., radiation workers, frequent flyers) show no significant increase in cancer risk.Moving ForwardFocus on your recovery: Your health is improving, and that’s the most important thing.Minimize future exposure: If you need imaging in the future, discuss with your doctor whether MRI or ultrasound (which don’t use ionizing radiation) could be alternatives.Don’t dwell on the past: The scans are done, and the additional cancer risk is minimal. Worrying about it won’t change the outcome, but it could negatively impact your mental health.Final ThoughtsYour concerns are valid, but the data suggests your worries about cancer risk are likely overstated. Your exposure is not trivial, but it’s also not in a range that would cause significant harm. Many people undergo similar or higher levels of radiation exposure over their lifetimes without ill effects. Focus on your recovery, maintain a healthy lifestyle, and try to let go of this worry. You’ve been through a lot, and it’s time to look forward.

172.question: Suddenly, everywhere I look, people are touting the benefits of stimulating the vagus nerve. What is the vagus nerve, and what does it actually do? Does stimulating it actually have all these positive effects people claim? (Stimulating digestion, lowering blood pressure, helping anxiety, etc.) 35/F/white/115 pounds/sertraline/Canada. Is stimulating the vagus nerve bullshit?
172.answer: t plays a crucial role in the parasympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for the body's rest and digest functions. The vagus nerve helps regulate heart rate, digestion, respiratory rate, and even aspects of mood and stress response. It also facilitates communication between the brain and organs like the heart, lungs, and gut.What Does the Vagus Nerve Do?Digestion: It stimulates stomach acid production and gut motility, aiding digestion.Heart Rate and Blood Pressure: It helps lower heart rate and blood pressure by promoting relaxation.Stress and Anxiety: It influences the release of neurotransmitters like serotonin and GABA, which can help reduce anxiety and promote calmness.Inflammation: It plays a role in controlling inflammation through the inflammatory reflex.Does Stimulating the Vagus Nerve Have Benefits?Stimulating the vagus nerve has been studied for its potential therapeutic effects, and some evidence supports its benefits:Digestion: Vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) can improve gut motility and reduce symptoms of conditions like gastroparesis.Blood Pressure: Techniques like deep breathing or VNS devices may help lower blood pressure in some individuals.Anxiety and Mood: VNS has been approved for treatment-resistant depression and may help reduce anxiety by promoting relaxation.Inflammation: Research suggests VNS might help manage inflammatory conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.However, the extent of these benefits can vary, and not all claims are equally supported by robust scientific evidence. Some methods of stimulation, like deep breathing, humming, or cold exposure, are low-risk and may provide mild benefits. Other methods, like implanted VNS devices, are more invasive and typically reserved for specific medical conditions.Is It Bullshit?Not entirely, but it’s important to approach the hype critically. While vagus nerve stimulation shows promise, many claims are based on preliminary studies or anecdotal evidence. For example:Natural Stimulation: Techniques like deep breathing, meditation, or yoga are safe and may help activate the parasympathetic nervous system, but their effects are often subtle.Medical Devices: Implanted VNS devices are FDA-approved for specific conditions like epilepsy and depression, but they’re not a cure-all.Overhyped Claims: Some wellness trends exaggerate the benefits of vagus nerve stimulation without strong evidence.For You Specifically:As a 35-year-old woman on sertraline (an SSRI for anxiety/depression), you might find relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation helpful for managing anxiety. However, always consult your healthcare provider before trying new therapies, especially if you have underlying health conditions.In summary, stimulating the vagus nerve isn’t bullshit, but it’s not a miracle cure either. Evidence-based methods can support overall well-being, but be cautious of exaggerated claims.

173.question: i was diagnosed when i was young with a seizure thing that goes away when youre 13, which impairs my ability to concentrate and gave me seizures while im sleeping about once every blood moon and my mom told me it was epilepsy, but see the thing is that shes not very good with english, and i have never had any trouble with seeing flashing lights. is it possible to have epilepsy but no trouble with seeing flashing colors?
173.answer: Yes, it is entirely possible to have epilepsy without being sensitive to flashing lights. Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures, but it manifests in many different ways, and not all people with epilepsy are affected by the same triggers.Key Points:Photosensitivity and Epilepsy: Sensitivity to flashing lights (photosensitivity) is a specific trigger for some people with epilepsy, but it is not a universal symptom. Only about 3-5% of people with epilepsy are photosensitive. This means the vast majority of people with epilepsy do not have seizures triggered by flashing lights.Types of Seizures: Epilepsy can cause various types of seizures, including focal (partial) seizures, generalized seizures, and absence seizures. Your description of having seizures while sleeping aligns with certain types of epilepsy, such as benign rolandic epilepsy (BRE), which often occurs during sleep and typically resolves by adolescence.Benign Rolandic Epilepsy: If you were diagnosed with a seizure disorder that was expected to resolve by around age 13, this sounds consistent with BRE. This condition is common in children and is characterized by seizures during sleep, often without other significant neurological issues. It is not typically associated with photosensitivity.Language Barriers and Diagnosis: If your mom struggled with English, it’s possible there was some miscommunication about your diagnosis. However, epilepsy is a broad term, and the absence of photosensitivity does not rule it out. A neurologist would have made the diagnosis based on your seizure history, EEG results, and other factors.Next Steps: If you’re still experiencing seizures or have concerns about your diagnosis, it’s a good idea to consult a neurologist. They can review your medical history, perform tests if necessary, and clarify whether your condition aligns with epilepsy or another seizure disorder.In summary, yes, you can have epilepsy without being sensitive to flashing lights. Your symptoms and history suggest a specific type of epilepsy that may have resolved, but if you have ongoing concerns, a medical professional can provide clarity.

174.question: Does radiation necrosis heal? 31 female 155 lbs Diagnosed w/ Brain AVM & 2 aneurysms 2009. - 3 gamma knife treatments in 2019. edications: Topamax, Trileptal, Zoloft, Wellbutrin, Clonidine, Vyvanse, Vitamin D, Folic Acid & had Kyleena IUD replaced February 16th. - important because vision symptoms started could be coincidence. Shortly after I had my new iud put in I started having issues with my left eye, vision became blurry”ish” on and off. For the next 3 weeks I Had slow thought processing during the time & some confusion. - Hard time finding words. I also had some “left neglect” symptoms but that’s normal for me when I get migraines because my left side goes numb so I related all of this to stress & the migraines until I started having muscle twitching in my left hand & wrist. - I started to improve end of March but My vision is still off sometimes & I’m not as sharp as I used to be. I Had an eeg in April which showed slowing, which I feel like is normal.. but I just had a follow up MRI & this is the report.. is someone able to explain it to me? No one has ever told me I had radiation necrosis. I guess I was always under the assumption my brain would heal itself after my radiation… but 4 years later it just seems to be getting worse. Does radiation necrosis heal/is it dangerous? Could this just be swelling? Did is progress fast from January 2022-April 2023? 4.. Since I’m not getting blood flow there is it basically the same thing as a ischemic stroke? What is FLAIR hyperintensity? Those are just questions off the top of my head. I don’t see a dr until June and google is not my friend.
174.answer: I’m not a doctor, but I can provide some general information to help you better understand your situation. Radiation necrosis is a known potential side effect of radiation therapy, including Gamma Knife treatments, and it can occur months to years after treatment. Here’s a breakdown of your questions:1. Does radiation necrosis heal?Radiation necrosis can sometimes stabilize or improve over time, but it often does not fully heal on its own. The brain tissue damaged by radiation may not regenerate, but symptoms can sometimes be managed with treatments such as:Steroids (e.g., dexamethasone) to reduce inflammation and swelling.Hyperbaric oxygen therapy to promote healing in damaged tissue.Bevacizumab (Avastin), a medication that can reduce swelling and improve symptoms in some cases.Surgical removal of necrotic tissue in severe cases.2. Is radiation necrosis dangerous?Radiation necrosis can be serious, especially if it causes significant swelling or affects critical areas of the brain. Symptoms depend on the location and size of the necrotic tissue. Common symptoms include:Cognitive changes (e.g., memory issues, difficulty finding words).Vision problems.Weakness or numbness.Seizures.Headaches.If left untreated, it can lead to permanent neurological deficits. However, with proper management, many people can stabilize or improve.3. Could this just be swelling?Yes, swelling (edema) is a common feature of radiation necrosis. The MRI report likely mentions FLAIR hyperintensity, which often indicates swelling or fluid buildup in the brain tissue. Steroids are typically used to reduce this swelling.4. Did it progress fast from January 2022 to April 2023?Without seeing your MRI reports, it’s hard to say how much progression occurred. Radiation necrosis can develop slowly over time, but changes in symptoms (e.g., vision issues, cognitive changes) may indicate progression. Your neurologist or neurosurgeon will compare your MRIs to assess the rate of change.5. Is it similar to an ischemic stroke?Radiation necrosis and ischemic strokes both involve damage to brain tissue, but they have different causes:Radiation necrosis is caused by damage from radiation therapy.Ischemic stroke is caused by a lack of blood flow due to a blocked artery.In both cases, the affected brain tissue may not function properly, but the underlying mechanisms and treatments differ.6. What is FLAIR hyperintensity?FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery) is an MRI sequence used to highlight abnormalities in the brain. FLAIR hyperintensity refers to areas that appear brighter than normal on the scan, often indicating:Swelling (edema).Scarring or gliosis.Radiation necrosis.Other forms of tissue damage.7. Vision symptoms and IUD coincidence?It’s unlikely that your Kyleena IUD directly caused your vision symptoms. However, hormonal changes can sometimes influence migraines or other neurological symptoms. Your vision issues are more likely related to the radiation necrosis or swelling in the brain, especially if the affected area is near the visual pathways.Next StepsDiscuss the MRI findings with your neurologist or neurosurgeon. They can explain the extent of the necrosis and whether it has progressed.Ask about treatment options to manage symptoms and reduce swelling.Monitor symptoms closely and report any new or worsening issues to your doctor.Key TakeawaysRadiation necrosis may not fully heal, but symptoms can often be managed.Swelling (edema) is a common feature and can be treated with steroids or other therapies.FLAIR hyperintensity on MRI indicates abnormal tissue, often due to swelling or scarring.Your vision and cognitive symptoms are likely related to the necrosis or swelling, not the IUD.It’s important to follow up with your doctor to get a personalized treatment plan. If your symptoms worsen before your June appointment, consider reaching out to your care team sooner.

175.question: Sex: M Age 48 Weight 235lbs Height: 6ft 2\" non smoker, non drinker epilepsy since birth, had his hemispheres separated about 15 years ago. 175.answer: I'm sorry to hear about your husband's struggles with epilepsy. It sounds like you're a very supportive partner, and it's clear that you're deeply invested in his well-being. 177.answer: I'm not a doctor, but based on what you're describing, it sounds like your symptoms could be related to epilepsy, specifically a type of seizure known as a focal aware seizure (previously called a simple partial seizure) or focal seizure with impaired awareness (complex partial seizure). These types of seizures can involve unusual sensations, emotions, or experiences, such as déjà vu, intense fear, or panic, and they may not always involve the classic convulsions people associate with epilepsy.Here’s why your symptoms might be related to epilepsy:Déjà vu and intense fear: These are classic symptoms of focal seizures, particularly those originating in the temporal lobe of the brain (temporal lobe epilepsy). The déjà vu feeling, overwhelming fear, and panic are often described as auras, which can precede a seizure or occur on their own.Confusion and memory gaps: After a focal seizure, it’s common to feel confused or have trouble remembering what happened during the episode. This is called the postictal state.Sleep disturbances: Seizures can occur during sleep, and you mentioned experiencing these episodes while sleeping. This is not uncommon in epilepsy.Frequency and fatigue: Having multiple episodes in a short period (like the 5 you mentioned) and feeling exhausted afterward are also consistent with seizure activity.However, it’s also possible that anxiety or panic attacks could be contributing to or mimicking some of these symptoms. Panic attacks can cause heart palpitations, hyperventilation, and intense fear, but they typically don’t involve the same level of confusion or memory gaps as seizures.What you should do:Consult your neurologist: Since you have a history of epilepsy and are taking Levetiracetam, it’s crucial to discuss these episodes with your neurologist. They may want to adjust your medication or investigate further.Keep a detailed diary: Record when these episodes happen, how long they last, what you experience, and any potential triggers (e.g., stress, lack of sleep, etc.). This can help your doctor identify patterns and determine if these are seizures, panic attacks, or something else.Consider an EEG or video monitoring: Your doctor might recommend an electroencephalogram (EEG) or video EEG monitoring to capture brain activity during one of these episodes. This can help determine if they are seizures.Rule out other causes: Your doctor may also want to rule out other conditions, such as migraines, sleep disorders, or psychological issues, which can sometimes mimic seizure-like symptoms.Important:Don’t stop or adjust your medication without consulting your doctor.If these episodes worsen or you experience a full-blown seizure, seek medical attention immediately.It’s great that you’re paying attention to these symptoms and seeking answers. Early intervention can help manage these episodes effectively and improve your quality of life.

179.question: So I’ve had three grand mal seizures so far, they happened once a year since 2017 and i went to see a doctor after the third time it happened.
