201.question: Girlfriend 20 y.o approx 55kg. Located Sydney, Australia. Jan 2017 my girlfriend had 39.7deg C fevers lasting approx 1 week. She was found in bed unresponsive, with side to side head movements. (One of my questions is what was this? Status epilepticus?) She was taken to ER and then into ICU with uncontrolled seizures, and not recovering inbetween episodes, & put into an induced coma. She was put on phenytoin initially, and I believe levetriacetam and sodium valproate followed shortly thereafter. My guess is also Midaz during the episodes. Her longest seizure (tonic-clonic) lasted 8 and a half minutes. Many tests later, abnormal EEG looking like the seizures were coming from left temporal lobe (her eyes/head get pushed to the right). Unremarkable MRI, all x-rays good. 2x spinal tap as the thoughts were auto-immune encephalitis (results: no evidence to support this aside from ancedotal). Little to no memories from 6 months ago with patchy memory for the last 2 years Discharged from ICU and we were back the next day as she was having more seizures. Was receiving prednisone and had 5 days IVIG for brain immflamation. A day later we were back in the ward, we would eventually be discharged about 3.5 weeks after initial admission. No seizures following the 1.5 months after discharge, but then they came back frequently. Her current seizures are not tonic clonic. She is concious throughout, still body though head, mouth and eyes behave just like a tonic clonic for someone with TLE. Lasting 30 secs to a min most of the time. Frequency is ~2x per week, nocturnal. I do have videos of the seizures. AEDs are: Phenytoin 300mg Levetriacetam (Keppra brand) 2500mg Sodium Valporate 2400mg Looking at introducing Vimpat shortly. My main questions: Was her head to head movement seizure activity? I know she was in status epilepticus/ prolonged seizure activity in ICU/ER. What are your thoughts on what she had? What are your thoughts on the current medication?
201.answer: Your girlfriend’s case is complex and involves several critical aspects of neurology, including status epilepticus, temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE), and potential autoimmune or inflammatory processes. Below, I’ll address your questions and provide some insights based on the information you’ve shared:1. Was her head-to-head movement seizure activity?The side-to-side head movements you described when she was found unresponsive could indeed be seizure activity, particularly if they were rhythmic and involuntary. This type of movement can be seen in focal seizures with impaired awareness (previously called complex partial seizures), especially if they originate from the temporal lobe. In her case, the abnormal EEG pointing to the left temporal lobe supports this possibility.The fact that she was unresponsive during these movements further suggests that this was likely ictal (seizure) activity rather than a post-ictal phenomenon or another cause of altered consciousness.2. Was she in status epilepticus?Yes, it sounds like she was in status epilepticus during her initial presentation. Status epilepticus is defined as a prolonged seizure (typically >5 minutes for tonic-clonic seizures) or recurrent seizures without recovery of consciousness in between. Her 8.5-minute tonic-clonic seizure and the need for an induced coma, along with the use of medications like midazolam (a benzodiazepine often used for acute seizure control), strongly support this diagnosis.Status epilepticus is a medical emergency and can be life-threatening if not treated promptly. The fact that she required ICU admission and multiple antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) highlights the severity of her condition.3. What are your thoughts on what she had?Initial Presentation: Her high fever, prolonged seizures, and unresponsiveness suggest an acute neurological insult. The differential diagnosis at the time likely included:Infectious encephalitis (e.g., viral or bacterial): Fever and seizures are common in encephalitis, though her spinal taps did not support this.Autoimmune encephalitis: This was considered given the use of prednisone and IVIG. While her spinal tap did not confirm this, autoimmune encephalitis can sometimes be seronegative (no antibodies detected). The improvement with immunotherapy (prednisone and IVIG) could suggest an autoimmune component.Febrile status epilepticus: Prolonged seizures triggered by fever, though this is more common in children.New-onset epilepsy: It’s possible that the fever triggered her first seizure in the context of an underlying predisposition to epilepsy.Current Diagnosis: Her ongoing seizures, EEG findings, and clinical features strongly suggest temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE). TLE is often associated with focal seizures that can secondarily generalize (as seen in her initial tonic-clonic seizures). Her current seizures (conscious but with head, mouth, and eye movements) are consistent with focal aware or impaired awareness seizures originating from the temporal lobe.4. What are your thoughts on the current medication?Her current AED regimen includes:Phenytoin (300 mg): A first-line AED for focal and tonic-clonic seizures. It’s effective but has side effects (e.g., gingival hyperplasia, osteoporosis) and requires monitoring of blood levels.Levetiracetam (2500 mg): A broad-spectrum AED with fewer drug interactions. It’s commonly used for focal and generalized seizures but can cause mood changes or irritability in some patients.Sodium valproate (2400 mg): Another broad-spectrum AED, effective for focal and generalized seizures. It’s particularly useful in TLE but has significant side effects (e.g., weight gain, tremor, teratogenicity).Vimpat (lacosamide): This is a newer AED that can be effective for focal seizures. It’s often used as an add-on therapy when seizures are not fully controlled. It’s generally well-tolerated but can cause dizziness or cardiac rhythm changes.Assessment of Current Regimen:She is on three AEDs at relatively high doses, yet she continues to have seizures (~2x per week). This suggests that her epilepsy is drug-resistant (refractory). The addition of Vimpat may help, but it’s important to monitor for side effects and interactions.Given her refractory epilepsy, you may want to discuss other treatment options with her neurologist, such as:Epilepsy surgery: If her seizures consistently originate from the left temporal lobe, resective surgery could be curative. A thorough pre-surgical evaluation (e.g., video-EEG monitoring, neuropsychological testing, and advanced imaging) would be needed.Vagus nerve stimulation (VNS): A device implanted in the chest that can reduce seizure frequency.Ketogenic diet: A high-fat, low-carb diet that can be effective in refractory epilepsy.Further immunotherapy: If an autoimmune component is still suspected, additional immunotherapy (e.g., rituximab) could be considered.5. Additional Considerations:Memory Issues: Her memory problems are likely related to her TLE. The temporal lobe is critical for memory formation, and seizures in this region can cause both ictal and interictal memory dysfunction.Nocturnal Seizures: Seizures during sleep are common in TLE. Ensuring good sleep hygiene and discussing nocturnal seizure control with her neurologist is important.Video Recordings: The videos of her seizures are valuable for her neurologist to review. They can help confirm the seizure type and guide treatment adjustments.Summary:Her initial presentation was likely status epilepticus triggered by fever, with a possible autoimmune or inflammatory component.Her current diagnosis is temporal lobe epilepsy, with ongoing focal seizures despite high-dose AEDs.Her current medications are appropriate but may need adjustment or augmentation (e.g., adding Vimpat). Consider discussing advanced treatment options (e.g., surgery, VNS) with her neurologist.Her memory issues and nocturnal seizures are consistent with TLE and should be addressed as part of her overall management.I strongly recommend continuing to work closely with her neurologist, ideally one specializing in epilepsy, to optimize her treatment and explore all available options.

202.question: Hi there! I recently found out that what I thought was just passing out 2 times were actually seizures. These happened a couple years apart, once in high school and once in college. They were both triggered by kinda similar events but both were from physical sensations. I experienced the aura, ictal and post-ictal phases of a seizure based on the research I have done over the past couple days. All of the feelings that I experienced afterwards line up with the symptoms post-seizure (including even some very strong spiritual connections (which can be associated with epilepsy).The first time I seized was when I got hit with a baseball in high school and was fine until I went to go sit back on the bench and then all the sudden I was like huh, something isn't right. Then next thing I know I wake up to 3 different adults standing over me holding my harms and keeping them from shaking. Luckily when I fell off the bench I fell onto catchers gear on instead of concrete. Then the next time was in college while a friend tried to pierce my ears. I again felt that same aura and began seizing. This time my partner was there and caught me from falling off my chair.I only realized recently that these were seizures after talking to my partner's mom who is a healthcare provider. As I was talking about epilepsy in one of my classes, I was suddenly inspired to look it up and find out more. Is it possible that I have a mild case of it? Should I go get tested? What are the implications for if I do? From the research I have done, it takes at least 2 seizures to get diagnosed so technically I have experienced that but years apart. Should I be worried about this or am I making a big deal out of nothing? I just don't know what to do.
202.answer: I'm sorry to hear about your experiences, but I'm glad you're taking steps to understand what's happening. It's important to address this thoughtfully, as seizures can have significant implications for your health and safety. Here's some guidance to help you navigate this situation:1. Could It Be Epilepsy?Epilepsy is a neurological condition characterized by recurrent, unprovoked seizures. While you've had two seizures, they were triggered by specific physical sensations (being hit by a baseball and ear piercing). These might be considered reflex seizures, which are triggered by specific stimuli, rather than unprovoked seizures typical of epilepsy.However, only a healthcare professional can determine whether your seizures are part of epilepsy or another condition. The fact that you experienced an aura, ictal, and post-ictal phases suggests these were indeed seizures, but the underlying cause needs to be investigated.2. Should You Get Tested?Yes, you should see a doctor. Even though your seizures were years apart, they were significant events that could indicate an underlying neurological issue. A neurologist can evaluate your history, perform tests, and determine whether further monitoring or treatment is needed.Diagnostic steps may include:EEG (Electroencephalogram): To check for abnormal brain activity.MRI or CT scan: To rule out structural issues in the brain.Blood tests: To check for metabolic or other systemic causes.Even if you don't have epilepsy, understanding why these seizures occurred is important for your safety and peace of mind.3. Implications of a DiagnosisIf you are diagnosed with epilepsy or another seizure disorder:Treatment: Medications (anti-seizure drugs) are often effective in preventing future seizures.Lifestyle adjustments: You may need to avoid known triggers, ensure adequate sleep, and manage stress.Driving restrictions: Many places have laws about driving after a seizure, so this could impact your ability to drive until you're seizure-free for a certain period.Safety precautions: You may need to take steps to avoid injury during a seizure, such as avoiding heights or swimming alone.If no underlying condition is found, you may still benefit from understanding your triggers and how to avoid them.4. Are You Making a Big Deal Out of Nothing?No, you're not. Seizures are a serious medical issue, and understanding their cause is crucial. Even if they are infrequent, they can pose risks, especially if they occur unexpectedly (e.g., while driving or swimming). Taking this seriously is the right thing to do.5. Next StepsSchedule an appointment with your primary care doctor or a neurologist. Bring detailed notes about your seizures, including:What happened before, during, and after each episode.Any triggers or patterns you've noticed.How long the episodes lasted and how you felt afterward.Avoid known triggers until you have more information.Educate yourself further about seizures and epilepsy, but rely on reputable sources like the Epilepsy Foundation or medical professionals.6. Emotional and Spiritual AspectsIt's not uncommon for people who experience seizures to describe profound emotional or spiritual experiences, especially during the aura or post-ictal phase. These feelings are valid and can be part of the neurological process. If these experiences are meaningful to you, consider discussing them with a counselor or therapist who understands the intersection of health and spirituality.Final ThoughtsYou're not overreacting—this is a legitimate health concern that deserves attention. Even if your seizures are infrequent, understanding their cause and how to manage them is important for your long-term well-being. Take the step to see a doctor, and don't hesitate to advocate for yourself if you feel your concerns aren't being taken seriously. You're doing the right thing by seeking answers!

203.question: Hello! I saw on the internet that occasionally some epilepsy medications such as Lamictal can react to HRT. This reaction can cause an increase in seizure activity. That of course is not my specific question. My question is does Depakote 1000mg therapeutic level, and Keppra 1000mg once at night reactive towards HRT treatments. As I am considering going through the process of transferring my gender from male to female via HRT treatments and I am rather worried that this may cause an increase in my seizures. My seizure disorder is: Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy Drugs I currently take: 1 1000mg Depakote pill in the AM, 1 1000mg Depakote pill in the PM, 1 500mg Keppra pill at night. 1 Calcium/Zinc/Magnesium supplement pill in the AM, 1 Vitamin D pill in the AM. 1 3mg meletonin pill prior to bed. 10mg of Adderal when needed. Epileptic triggers: Sleep, anxiety. These medications may change a bit, but the general amount will stay the same. If anyone could give me insight on this topic please tell me. As I am a shy person and bringing this up with my neurologist would only complicate my appointments with him. So I’d rather learn more prior to bringing it up. You can be specific in medications, dosages and terminology as I do know a lot about epilepsy and studying neurology currently.
203.answer: Hello! It's great that you're doing thorough research before starting HRT, especially given your medical history with Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME) and your current medication regimen. Let’s break this down step by step to address your concerns about potential interactions between HRT and your epilepsy medications (Depakote and Keppra).1. HRT and Epilepsy: General ConsiderationsHormonal changes, particularly fluctuations in estrogen and progesterone, can influence seizure thresholds in individuals with epilepsy. Estrogen is generally considered pro-convulsant (lowers seizure threshold), while progesterone has anti-convulsant properties (raises seizure threshold).For transgender women (male-to-female), HRT typically involves estrogen therapy, often combined with anti-androgens (e.g., spironolactone) or other androgen blockers. These hormonal changes could theoretically affect seizure control, though the extent varies between individuals.2. Depakote (Valproate) and HRTDepakote is a broad-spectrum antiepileptic drug (AED) that is also used as a mood stabilizer. It is metabolized in the liver and has several interactions to consider:Estrogen Interaction: Estrogen can increase the metabolism of valproate via induction of hepatic enzymes (e.g., CYP450), potentially reducing its serum levels and efficacy. This could theoretically lead to breakthrough seizures.Monitoring: If you start HRT, your neurologist may need to monitor your valproate levels more closely and adjust the dose if necessary.Anti-Androgen Interaction: Spironolactone, a common anti-androgen used in MTF HRT, is generally safe with valproate, but it’s important to monitor for side effects like electrolyte imbalances (e.g., hyperkalemia).3. Keppra (Levetiracetam) and HRTKeppra is another broad-spectrum AED with a relatively low risk of drug interactions. It is primarily renally excreted and does not undergo significant hepatic metabolism.Estrogen Interaction: Keppra is unlikely to interact directly with estrogen or other HRT components. However, hormonal changes could still indirectly affect seizure control.Monitoring: Keppra levels are not typically monitored, but you should remain vigilant for any changes in seizure frequency or side effects.4. Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy (JME) and HRTJME is a lifelong condition that is often well-controlled with medications like valproate and levetiracetam. However, it is sensitive to hormonal changes, sleep deprivation, and stress.Sleep and Anxiety: Since sleep and anxiety are your primary triggers, it’s important to ensure that HRT does not exacerbate these factors. For example, estrogen can sometimes affect mood and sleep patterns, so close monitoring is key.5. Practical RecommendationsConsult Your Neurologist and Endocrinologist: While it’s understandable that you’re hesitant to bring this up, it’s crucial to involve your neurologist and an endocrinologist experienced in transgender care. They can work together to:Monitor your AED levels (especially valproate) during HRT initiation.Adjust your medication doses if necessary.Address any changes in seizure frequency or side effects.Baseline Labs: Before starting HRT, consider getting baseline labs for valproate levels, liver function, and hormone levels.Gradual HRT Initiation: Starting HRT at a low dose and titrating up slowly may help minimize the risk of seizure exacerbation.Seizure Diary: Keep a detailed seizure diary to track any changes in frequency, type, or triggers after starting HRT.6. Specific HRT MedicationsEstrogen Options: Common forms include oral estradiol, transdermal patches, or injections. Transdermal patches may have a more stable hormonal profile and lower risk of hepatic enzyme induction compared to oral estrogen.Anti-Androgens: Spironolactone is commonly used and generally safe with your current medications. Alternatives like bicalutamide or GnRH agonists may also be considered, depending on your overall health.7. Other ConsiderationsBone Health: Valproate and estrogen both have implications for bone health. Ensure adequate calcium, vitamin D, and weight-bearing exercise to mitigate any risks.Mental Health: HRT can have significant psychological effects. If anxiety worsens, it could indirectly increase seizure risk. Consider working with a therapist experienced in transgender care.SummaryDepakote: Monitor levels closely, as estrogen may reduce its efficacy.Keppra: Unlikely to interact directly with HRT, but remain vigilant for changes in seizure control.HRT: Start low and go slow, with close monitoring by both your neurologist and endocrinologist.Communication: While it’s great to educate yourself, discussing this with your healthcare team is essential for safe and effective care.If you have any further questions or need clarification, feel free to ask! Good luck with your transition and your studies in neurology!

204.question: Female Age: 61 Weight: 185 Height: 5'2\" Heavy Smoker, Non-Drinker Medications: several blood pressure, gabapentin, depecote, also on anxiety med don't know the name right off.I'm looking for help, not diagnosis, but possible causes, reasons, some ideas of what to bring to the doctor. It's long and winded please read. I need help. Starting early last year (2018) she started having these falling spells. She'd be walking down the hall and just her legs would give out and start shaking back and forth then she'd be on the floor. After telling the doctor several times finally went to a neurologist. NONE of her doctors have ever seen one of these spells so they don't know exactly what we are talking about which is infuriating. She'll fall out of bed; she broke/fractured her back summer 2018 by falling out of bed. While in the hospital for a couple days...NEVER had a spell. Which was also infuriating because at home they happen several times a day. At first she was incoherent and didn't know where she was after having these spells and falls. She also has trembling of the hands and jerks. She's often burning holes in her clothes or bedding because she'll just drop the cigarette from a jerk, she's broken several glasses, plates, bowls. Now, a year later she's been diagnosed with epilepsy (summer/fall 2018) and is on depekote to deal with it and is supposed to be off gabapentin cuz they definitely don't mix for her. Causes great confusion and more falling spells. But now with advice from doctor she's on gabapentin in the morning and then depekote at night. Not supposed to mix with each other that way, however, she's still greatly confused. She has a 9th grade education didn't get a lot of what we learned in school as kids, but she wasn't dumb she could figure things out. Now, she can't spell, her memory is so gone, she barely remembers our childhood, she has no fricken idea how to spell or do simple math anymore. I blame the gabapentin and depekote together because that's when it started. But doc swears they don't do that...well I'm sorry your degree cannot tell me something I'm literally seeing every fucking day. But I digress. Now, she still has \"seizures\" is what they are calling them, but she doesn't fall she leans on something and is very coherent thru and all her body does is her legs violently shake back and forth like she's trying to balance on a surf board and its wildly going back and forth. She doesn't lose consciousness at all anymore, she's not as dingy as she was like last summer, but she's still losing basic skills every day. She does have a lot of plaque on the brain so my sister and I are thinking maybe it's early on-set Alzheimer's, but I truly honestly believe it is the depekote and gabapentin mixture. Doc doesn't think so. I have no medical degree obviously, but I see this shit going down every day. Like legit we talk about dinner around 10am so we can take it out of freezer and we'll discuss 2 or 3 meals and then ask everybody and then we will figure it out. Within 30 minutes of taking the meat out to thaw, she's already forgotten what we are having and then takes something else out. Then, we have two meats out and then have the other one the following night and then she's trying to figure out dinner for that night and forgets she's already taken something out. It's really aggravating, but I try not to get mad, but my sister gets thoroughly upset because it's like this every single day. And currently my husband and I live with my mom her husband (step dad) and my sister. Too expensive to live on own and my mom and stepdad can't afford all the bills by themselves and they are both on social security. She doesn't not have any medical insurance. We are hoping come March 2020 she'll be accepted on Medicare, but she was rejected this year, so we are just praying and hoping. This is causing me great anxiety; I have anxiety over losing my mom because of my grandma dying years ago. It kicked in some major anxiety of my mom dying. And this all causes me to not want to get a job after graduation. I graduate college in May '20 and I'm super excited about my career prospects I technically have 2 jobs lined up if I want them. I'm being headhunted and apparently my grades and studies are rock solid. IDK, but this causes me to want to just stay home and be with my mom daily and not miss anything, that FOMO thing going on. If we go by history with her family traced back to a couple hundred years ago; all females in this certain lineage all die at 67 and 5 months. She just happens to be in line, so do I. It's crazy, weird, and not exactly accurate, but with how her health has gone horrible since turning 60 I feel it's going to be accurate. And that scares me.
204.answer: I'm really sorry to hear about your mom's health struggles and the stress this is causing you and your family. It sounds like you're dealing with a very complex and challenging situation. While I can't provide a diagnosis, I can offer some insights and suggestions that might help you and your family navigate this situation and prepare for discussions with her doctors.Possible Causes and Considerations:Medication Side Effects:Gabapentin and Depakote (valproate) are both medications that can cause cognitive side effects, including confusion, memory issues, and drowsiness. While your doctor may not attribute her symptoms to these medications, it’s worth noting that polypharmacy (using multiple medications) can increase the risk of adverse effects, especially in older adults.Gabapentin is known to cause dizziness, unsteadiness, and cognitive impairment in some people, particularly at higher doses or when combined with other central nervous system depressants.Depakote can also cause tremors, confusion, and memory problems, especially in older adults or those with pre-existing cognitive issues.Epilepsy or Seizure-like Activity:The episodes you describe (legs shaking, falls, and tremors) could be related to her epilepsy diagnosis. However, it’s also possible that other conditions, such as non-epileptic seizures (psychogenic or related to stress/anxiety), could be contributing. These can sometimes mimic epileptic seizures but have different underlying causes.The fact that she didn’t have any episodes in the hospital could suggest that environmental or psychological factors (e.g., stress, familiarity with surroundings) play a role.Cognitive Decline:The memory loss, confusion, and difficulty with basic tasks (e.g., spelling, math) could be related to early-onset dementia (e.g., Alzheimer’s disease) or another form of cognitive impairment. The presence of plaque on the brain (if confirmed by imaging) could support this possibility.However, cognitive decline can also be caused or exacerbated by medications, chronic illness, or untreated conditions like vitamin deficiencies (e.g., B12 deficiency) or thyroid dysfunction.Other Potential Causes:Orthostatic Hypotension: A sudden drop in blood pressure when standing could cause falls or near-falls. This is common in older adults, especially those on blood pressure medications.Parkinson’s Disease or Parkinsonian Symptoms: Tremors, jerks, and balance issues could be related to a movement disorder. Some medications (e.g., antipsychotics, anti-nausea drugs) can cause Parkinsonian symptoms as a side effect.Chronic Smoking-Related Issues: Long-term smoking can lead to vascular problems, which might contribute to cognitive decline or other neurological symptoms.Anxiety or Psychogenic Factors: Severe anxiety or stress can manifest physically, including tremors, jerks, or even seizure-like episodes.Questions and Tests to Discuss with Her Doctor:Medication Review:Ask for a thorough review of all her medications, including potential interactions and side effects. Consider asking if gabapentin or Depakote could be contributing to her cognitive decline or tremors.Inquire about alternative medications or adjustments to her current regimen.Cognitive Assessment:Request a formal cognitive evaluation to assess for dementia or other cognitive impairments. This might include tests like the MMSE (Mini-Mental State Examination) or MoCA (Montreal Cognitive Assessment).Ask if imaging (e.g., MRI or CT scan) has been done recently to assess the extent of plaque or other brain changes.Seizure Evaluation:If her episodes are still occurring despite treatment, ask if further testing (e.g., EEG monitoring) could help clarify whether they are truly epileptic seizures or something else.Blood Tests:Request blood tests to rule out reversible causes of cognitive decline, such as:Vitamin B12 deficiencyThyroid dysfunction (hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism)Electrolyte imbalancesLiver or kidney dysfunctionOrthostatic Blood Pressure Check:Ask her doctor to check her blood pressure while lying down, sitting, and standing to rule out orthostatic hypotension.Psychiatric Evaluation:If anxiety or stress is suspected to play a role in her episodes, consider asking for a referral to a psychiatrist or psychologist.Practical Steps to Take:Keep a Detailed Journal:Document her symptoms, including the frequency and duration of her episodes, any triggers, and her cognitive and behavioral changes. This can help her doctors better understand what’s happening.Medication Management:Ensure she’s taking her medications exactly as prescribed. Consider using a pill organizer or setting reminders to avoid missed doses or accidental double-dosing.Safety Measures:Make her environment as safe as possible to prevent falls (e.g., remove tripping hazards, install grab bars, use a medical alert system).Support for Caregivers:Caring for a loved one with complex health issues can be overwhelming. Consider seeking support through caregiver support groups or counseling to help manage your anxiety and stress.Advocate for Her Care:If you feel her concerns aren’t being addressed, consider seeking a second opinion from another neurologist or specialist.Final Thoughts:It’s clear that you care deeply about your mom and are doing everything you can to help her. While her situation is complex, advocating for thorough testing and exploring all possible causes can help ensure she gets the best care possible. Don’t hesitate to push for answers or seek additional opinions if you feel her current treatment plan isn’t addressing her needs.Take care of yourself, too—your well-being is just as important as hers. Wishing you and your family strength and clarity as you navigate this difficult time.

205.question: My daughter is currently 7yrs old, epileptic (\"generalized\", idiopathic), ADD/ADHD, PDD, 15q26.1 microdeletion (not inherited). She's still illiterate, has issues getting to the bathroom (has a lot of \"accidents\") and lacks some finesse in her fine & gross motor skills. She's also slightly bow-legged. She's been seizure-free for over two years. When seizures initially presented, she was prescribed Topamax but it made her so dizzy she was unable to walk straight. She switched to a very low dose of valproic acid (maxed at 4mL 2/day). No other regular meds. About six months ago, her neurologist felt safe in discontinuing her valproic acid. Even though it was what the doc considered an extremely low dose, we noticed a huge change in our daughter's behavior. She just seems more \"present\" and aware of her surroundings. A few times she's had mood swings (sadness and crying) seemingly out of nowhere but all other aspects have been positive. Her PDD-related delays notwithstanding, she's made major strides in language, communication, following directions, etc; it's as if she previously wasn't aware of what was going on around her. When she was 2-3yrs old, we always marveled at what a happy-go-lucky child she was, never crying or throwing tantrums. Without the medication, she seems like she's much more like what we expected from that history. So, what gives? Valproic acid is also used for bi-polar so I can only assume there may have been a mood stabilizing effect of some sort but is there any explanation for the other communication-/social-related behavioral changes?
205.answer: It sounds like your daughter has made significant progress since discontinuing valproic acid, which is wonderful to hear. Valproic acid (VPA) is indeed a medication with a broad range of effects, and its impact on your daughter's behavior and development could be multifaceted. Here are some possible explanations for the changes you've observed:1. Cognitive and Behavioral Effects of Valproic AcidSedation and Cognitive Blunting: Valproic acid can have sedative effects, which may have contributed to your daughter appearing less "present" or aware of her surroundings. By discontinuing the medication, these sedative effects may have lifted, allowing her to engage more fully with her environment.Mood Stabilization: As you mentioned, valproic acid is used as a mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder. While your daughter does not have a bipolar diagnosis, the medication may have had a dampening effect on her emotional responsiveness. Without it, her emotions may be more pronounced, which could explain the occasional mood swings (sadness and crying) but also her increased engagement and awareness.2. Neurodevelopmental ImpactDevelopmental Delays and Medication Effects: Children with neurodevelopmental conditions like PDD (Pervasive Developmental Disorder) and ADHD can be particularly sensitive to medications that affect the central nervous system. Valproic acid may have subtly influenced her cognitive and social development, and discontinuing it could have allowed her natural developmental trajectory to emerge more clearly.Improved Communication and Social Skills: The lifting of sedative effects and increased alertness may have made it easier for her to process language, follow directions, and engage socially. This could explain the strides she has made in communication and social interaction.3. Seizure Control and Brain FunctionSeizure Freedom and Brain Development: Being seizure-free for over two years is a significant milestone. Seizures, even subclinical ones, can interfere with brain development and function. With her seizures well-controlled and now off medication, her brain may be functioning more optimally, allowing for improved cognitive and social skills.Neuroplasticity: The brain, especially in children, has a remarkable ability to rewire and adapt. Being off valproic acid may have allowed her brain to reorganize and develop more efficiently, contributing to her progress.4. Individual Variability in Medication ResponseSensitivity to Medications: Every child responds differently to medications. Your daughter may have been particularly sensitive to the effects of valproic acid, even at a low dose. Discontinuing it may have removed a barrier to her natural development.Mood and Emotional Regulation: The occasional mood swings you describe could be a result of her brain adjusting to the absence of the medication. Over time, these may stabilize as her brain continues to adapt.5. Other ConsiderationsFine and Gross Motor Skills: While valproic acid is not typically associated with significant motor skill impairments, its sedative effects could have indirectly affected her motor development. Being off the medication may have allowed her to practice and improve these skills more effectively.Bowel and Bladder Control: The improvement in her awareness and ability to follow directions may also be contributing to better bathroom habits, though this is an area where additional support (e.g., behavioral interventions or occupational therapy) might still be beneficial.Next StepsMonitor Progress: Continue to observe her development closely. If the mood swings persist or worsen, it may be worth discussing with her neurologist or a developmental pediatrician.Therapies and Interventions: Given her progress, she may benefit from ongoing speech therapy, occupational therapy, and behavioral interventions to further support her development.Regular Follow-ups: Maintain regular follow-ups with her neurologist to ensure that she remains seizure-free and to monitor her overall development.In summary, the changes you've observed in your daughter since discontinuing valproic acid are likely due to a combination of reduced sedation, improved brain function, and her natural developmental trajectory. It's a positive sign that she is more engaged and aware, and with continued support, she may continue to make significant strides in her development.

206.question: I'm a 23 year old guy. I recently had an ambulatory EEG as I occaisionally have partial siezures and I recieved a copy of a letter sent between the person who looked at the EEG recording and my neurologist. In the letter it says \"There were spike and wave discharges over the right frontotemporal and central regions maximally frontal\". I can't get hold of the neurologist right now so I was just wondering if someone here could tell me what that means as i didn't have an actual siezure at any point during the recording.
206.answer: The phrase spike and wave discharges over the right frontotemporal and central regions maximally frontal in your EEG report refers to specific electrical patterns observed in your brain activity during the recording. Here's a breakdown of what it means:Spike and wave discharges: These are abnormal electrical patterns seen on an EEG. They are often associated with epilepsy or seizure activity. Spikes are sharp waves, and when they are followed by a slower wave, they form a spike and wave pattern. These discharges can indicate increased excitability in the brain, even if you didn't have a visible seizure during the recording.Right frontotemporal and central regions: This specifies the location in your brain where these abnormal discharges were most prominent. The right frontotemporal region is the area near the front and side of your brain on the right side, and the central region refers to the middle part of the brain. These areas are involved in various functions, including movement, language, and sensory processing.Maximally frontal: This means that the spike and wave discharges were most pronounced in the frontal lobe of your brain, which is responsible for functions like decision-making, problem-solving, and controlling voluntary movements.Even though you didn't have an actual seizure during the recording, the presence of spike and wave discharges suggests that there is abnormal electrical activity in your brain, which could be related to your history of partial seizures. This finding helps your neurologist better understand the nature of your condition and may guide treatment decisions.It's important to discuss these results with your neurologist when you can, as they can provide more context and explain how this finding relates to your symptoms and treatment plan. They may recommend adjustments to your medication, further testing, or other interventions based on this information.

207.question: I am a 42 year old male. Feel free to remove this post if it is not appropriate for this sub, or maybe re-direct me to a better place. Scan of my brain (shows cyst) and an EEG (normal results). ER visit was in San Diego and all heart and brain tests came back normal. Please anyone who might know resources, questions to ask, or anything; I will be extremely grateful. Keppra makes me agitated and irritable and not myself and not helping with seizures. 207.answer: I'm really sorry to hear about your situation, and I appreciate you sharing your story. Navigating the healthcare system can be incredibly overwhelming, especially when you're dealing with serious health issues. Here are some steps and resources that might help you:1. Medi-Cal (California's Medicaid Program)Eligibility: Medi-Cal provides free or low-cost health coverage to low-income individuals and families. Given your current income and health condition, you might qualify. Even though your unemployment benefits are currently putting you over the income limit, there are exceptions for people with disabilities.Disability Determination: If your condition (e.g., seizures, brain cyst) is severe enough to prevent you from working, you might qualify for Medi-Cal based on disability. You would need a doctor to certify that you are disabled. The doctor in Mexico might be able to provide this, but you may need to get a U.S. doctor to confirm the diagnosis.Application: You can apply for Medi-Cal through Covered California or directly through your county social services office. Be sure to mention your health condition and the impact it has on your ability to work.2. Covered California (ObamaCare)Special Enrollment Period: If you lose your unemployment benefits, that would qualify you for a Special Enrollment Period, allowing you to sign up for a plan outside the usual open enrollment period.Cost-Sharing Reductions: Even if you don't qualify for subsidies based on income, you might still be eligible for cost-sharing reductions that lower your out-of-pocket costs (like deductibles and copayments).3. County Medical ServicesSan Diego County: Some counties in California have programs for low-income residents who don't qualify for Medi-Cal. Contact the San Diego County Health and Human Services Agency to see if they have any programs that could help you.Charity Care: Some hospitals offer charity care programs for patients who can't afford to pay their medical bills. You can contact the hospital where you had the ER visit to see if they have such a program.4. Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI) and Supplemental Security Income (SSI)SSDI: If your condition is severe enough to prevent you from working for at least 12 months, you might qualify for SSDI. This program provides monthly payments to people who are unable to work due to a disability.SSI: SSI is a needs-based program for low-income individuals with disabilities. If you qualify for SSI, you will automatically qualify for Medi-Cal.Application Process: The application process can be lengthy and often requires substantial medical documentation. It might be helpful to consult with a disability attorney or advocate to assist with your application.5. Short-Term DisabilityState Disability Insurance (SDI): If you have been paying into the state disability insurance program through your payroll taxes, you might be eligible for short-term disability benefits. This could provide some income while you are unable to work.Doctor's Certification: You will need a doctor to certify that you are unable to work due to your medical condition.6. Community Health CentersFree or Low-Cost Care: Community health centers provide medical services on a sliding fee scale based on income. You can find a health center near you through the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) website.Mental Health Services: Given the stress and anxiety you're experiencing, it might be helpful to seek mental health support. Many community health centers offer mental health services.7. Non-Profit OrganizationsPatient Advocacy Groups: There are non-profit organizations that help people navigate the healthcare system and access care. Examples include the Patient Advocate Foundation and the HealthWell Foundation.Epilepsy Foundation: If your condition is related to seizures, the Epilepsy Foundation might have resources and support services that could help you.8. Medical Treatment in MexicoContinuity of Care: If you continue to seek treatment in Mexico, try to maintain continuity of care by seeing the same doctor or clinic. This will help ensure that your medical history is well-documented.Translation Services: If you need help translating your medical records from Spanish to English, there are services available that can assist with this.9. Legal AidLegal Assistance: If you're struggling with medical bills or insurance issues, legal aid organizations might be able to help. They can assist with negotiating medical bills, appealing insurance denials, and more.10. Next StepsCounty Worker: When you speak with the county worker, be sure to explain your entire situation, including your health condition, financial situation, and the impact on your ability to work. Ask specifically about any programs for people with disabilities or those in transitional periods.Documentation: Gather all your medical records, test results, and any other documentation that supports your case. This will be important for applying for disability benefits or Medi-Cal.Final ThoughtsIt's clear that you're in a difficult situation, but there are resources and programs that might be able to help. Don't hesitate to reach out to multiple organizations and agencies to explore all your options. It might also be helpful to consult with a social worker or patient advocate who can guide you through the process.I hope this information helps, and I wish you the best of luck in getting the care and support you need.

208.question: F 25, 165 lbs So i know this sounds like a weird question. But I have 100% confirmed case of temporal lobe epilepsy diagnosed since age 3. Since then ive had strokes, had brain surgery, developed an autoimmune disorder (antiphospholipid syndrome btw) . So needless to say, my brain has taken a beating. So why do i think im having non epileptic seizures? Well these seizures tend to only happen at work. They present differently than my normal seizures. And afterwards i don't have the stereotypical post-ictal headache. I usually have A headache. But not as bad as I'd usually expect from just having a seizure. The only thing that leads me to thinking maybe they are real is that i tend to have an aura before they happen. The same aura as my normal seizures. (A cold tingly feeling on thebleft side of the body, vidual disturbance in the left eye, sinking feeling in the stonach) But instead of having a normal simple partial or worse complex partial seizure. I have this weird episode where my face is twitching (sometimes a limb or two) and im having trouble breathing(coworkers have described it to me). So what's going on? Am i having a new manifestation of seizures that cause difficulty breathing? Or am i having nonepileptic seizures triggered by work stress? And would nonepileptic seuzures come with an aura before them? Also would someone who is having non epileptic seizures be aware that they are having non epileptic seizures? Sorry if im going in a circle. It's just confusing having epilepsy for 20+ years just for your condition to change.
208.answer: I'm sorry to hear about the challenges you've been facing with your health. It sounds like you're dealing with a complex and confusing situation, and it's understandable that you're seeking clarity. Let's break down some of the key points you've raised:1. Epileptic vs. Non-Epileptic SeizuresEpileptic Seizures: These are caused by abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Given your history of temporal lobe epilepsy, you're familiar with the typical symptoms, such as auras, post-ictal headaches, and specific seizure types (simple partial, complex partial, etc.).Non-Epileptic Seizures (NES): These can look like epileptic seizures but are not caused by abnormal electrical activity in the brain. They are often related to psychological stress or trauma and are classified as a type of functional neurological disorder (FND). NES can be triggered by emotional or physical stress, and they may occur in people with or without a history of epilepsy.2. Your SymptomsAura: The fact that you experience an aura before these episodes is interesting. Auras are typically associated with epileptic seizures, as they are essentially a simple partial seizure that precedes a larger event. However, some people with NES may also report aura-like symptoms, especially if they have a history of epilepsy.Different Presentation: The episodes you describe (face twitching, trouble breathing, less severe headache) do sound different from your typical seizures. This could suggest a different underlying cause, such as NES.Work-Related Stress: The fact that these episodes tend to happen at work could point to stress as a trigger. Stress is a common trigger for both epileptic and non-epileptic seizures, but it's particularly associated with NES.3. Awareness During SeizuresEpileptic Seizures: Depending on the type, you may or may not be aware during the seizure. For example, in complex partial seizures, awareness is often impaired.Non-Epileptic Seizures: People with NES are often aware of their surroundings during the episode, though this can vary. Some people may be partially aware, while others may not be aware at all.4. What Could Be Going On?New Manifestation of Epilepsy: It's possible that your epilepsy is evolving, and you're experiencing a new type of seizure. Epilepsy can change over time, especially if there have been significant changes in your brain (e.g., strokes, surgery).Non-Epileptic Seizures: Given the different presentation and the fact that these episodes are happening in a specific context (work), it's also possible that you're experiencing NES. The presence of an aura doesn't rule this out, especially if you have a long history of epilepsy.Mixed Seizures: Some people experience both epileptic and non-epileptic seizures, which can make diagnosis and management more challenging.5. Next StepsMedical Evaluation: It's important to discuss these new symptoms with your neurologist. They may recommend further testing, such as an EEG during one of these episodes, to determine whether the seizures are epileptic or non-epileptic.Video EEG Monitoring: This can be particularly helpful in distinguishing between epileptic and non-epileptic seizures. During a video EEG, you would be monitored for both brain activity and physical symptoms, which can help clarify the nature of the episodes.Psychological Evaluation: If NES is suspected, a psychological evaluation may be helpful to explore potential stressors or underlying psychological factors that could be contributing to the episodes.Stress Management: Regardless of the cause, stress management techniques (e.g., mindfulness, therapy, relaxation exercises) may help reduce the frequency of these episodes.6. Would You Be Aware?If these are non-epileptic seizures, it's possible that you could be aware during the episodes, but this isn't always the case. Awareness can vary depending on the individual and the specific nature of the seizure.ConclusionIt's definitely possible that you're experiencing a new type of seizure, whether epileptic or non-epileptic. The presence of an aura doesn't necessarily rule out NES, especially given your history. The best course of action is to work closely with your neurologist to investigate these episodes further. They may recommend additional testing or a referral to a specialist in functional neurological disorders.It's also worth considering that stress at work could be a contributing factor, so addressing any underlying stressors or seeking support from a therapist might be beneficial.I hope this helps, and I wish you the best in getting to the bottom of this.

209.question: (24F, 5\"7, 14st 11, no drugs/drink/smoking) Current medical conditions: endometriosis, pcos, non epileptic seziures. Current medication: mirtazapine I was treated for epilepsy from the age of 9 to 23 with a few different medications. I have been on topiramate, lamotragine, epilim and keppra. The dose varied from.a few 100mg to 1000mg over the years. At 23 I found out my seizures were non epileptic and came off my medicines. Since then, my mood has had bigger swings. I've been the lowest I've ever been in my life, ending up in a&e trying to end my life a few weeks ago. However, my mood rapidly changes over a day from extremely low to being a bit reckless. I have ended up in trouble with my money like this. This usually lasts about a week then I become low again. My question was whether is was possible that after 14 years on anti epilepsy drugs, they were unintentionally treating something related to my mood?
209.answer: I'm really sorry to hear about the struggles you've been facing. It sounds like you've been through a lot, and I appreciate you sharing your story. To answer your question: yes, it is possible that the anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) you were on for 14 years could have had an impact on your mood, and coming off them might have contributed to the mood swings you're experiencing now.Many anti-epileptic medications have mood-stabilizing properties and are sometimes used to treat mood disorders, even in people without epilepsy. For example:Lamotrigine: This is commonly used as a mood stabilizer, particularly for bipolar disorder, to prevent depressive episodes.Topiramate: While primarily used for epilepsy, it has also been used off-label to treat mood disorders and stabilize mood.Valproate (Epilim): This is another medication often used to treat bipolar disorder and stabilize mood.Keppra (Levetiracetam): This is less commonly associated with mood stabilization, but some people do experience mood-related side effects, both positive and negative, while on it.Given that you were on these medications for so long, it's possible that they were inadvertently helping to regulate your mood. When you stopped taking them, it could have disrupted this balance, leading to the mood swings and emotional instability you're now experiencing.What You Can Do:Discuss with Your Doctor: It’s important to bring this up with your psychiatrist or GP. They may want to explore whether a mood stabilizer or a different approach to managing your mood swings could help. Since you’re already on mirtazapine (an antidepressant), they might consider adjusting your treatment plan.Mood Tracking: Keeping a mood diary can help you and your doctor identify patterns in your mood swings. This can be useful for diagnosing any underlying mood disorders, such as bipolar disorder or cyclothymia.Therapy: Psychological therapies, such as cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) or dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), can be very helpful for managing mood swings and emotional regulation.Review Your History: Since you have a history of non-epileptic seizures (which can be linked to psychological stress or trauma), it might be worth exploring whether there are underlying emotional or psychological factors contributing to both your seizures and your mood swings.Consider a Psychiatric Evaluation: Given the severity of your mood swings and the recent crisis, a thorough psychiatric evaluation could help clarify whether there’s an underlying mood disorder that needs to be addressed.Important:Your safety is the top priority. If you ever feel at risk of harming yourself again, please seek immediate help by going to A&E or contacting a crisis helpline. You’re not alone, and there are people who can support you through this.Let me know if you’d like help finding resources or support in your area. You’re taking a really important step by reaching out and thinking about these issues.

210.question: 33 Year Old Male, 5 Feet 7 Inches, about 165LB, Caucasian, Persistent headache varying in intensity, lasting months. Epileptic. Started with Essential Tremor at ~12-13. Full blown bed-ridden migraines ~15-16. Myoclonic Seizures 17. Tonic-Clonic seizures 18. Migraines disappeared. Varying seizures becoming more frequent and severe until current age. Smoke pipe tobacco. 1-3 pipes/day. No other non-prescribed drugs including alcohol EXCEPT Ibuprofren 200mg and Kratom 5 grams 3x daily for headaches when they're in full force. Acamprosate 666mg 3x daily, Baclofen 20mg 3x daily, Levitiracetam 1500mg 2x daily, Zonisamide 200mg nightly. Hydroxyzine 25mg nightly. Librium 10-30mg as needed for seizure clusters. Zofran 4-8mg as needed or every 4 hours. Propranolol 20mg 2x/day (they thought it'd help for anxiety about pending seizures). Seizure/Migraine history is same as an uncle. Everything progressed the same. Whether it's relevant I'm not sure. The severe \"I can't stand light/sound, I want to cry\" type migraines mostly disappeared and only happen rarely rather than almost daily now. I do however get long periods of headaches. Sometimes like today almost comparable to the migraines just not as intense. Today for example, strong pain starting behind right eye. It's throbbing and radiating through the whole right side of my head back to my neck. It's spread into the left of my head to an extent but not as intense. I'm past 3 months of this now. Some days like this, some days it's more general (as in, more even around the head and less throbbing but more of a constant annoying pain). I've two PCPs, an epileptologist and another neurologist however my epilepsy is my primary focus and I've had little time to go over these headaches. I used to take Imitrex and something else when I had the severe migraines but they didn't help. Nothing OTC seems to help. I only continue the Ibuprofren due to having cubital tunnel syndrome and having it recommended for that. The kratom helps dull the pain a little. I know it's an opiod. Honestly in the past I've taken hydrocodone and oxycodone for these headaches and they also only dulled it. esting pulse is around 40-60bpm. Blood pressure averages around 110/60 give or take. I'm not sure if these are tension headaches, mild migraines or somehow epilepsy related. Provided my migraines happened before my seizures started I'm wondering about the latter however if you're a doctor I'm sure you know it can be hard to tell with these things. Alike with migraines and epileptic episodes, I get visual auras with these headaches - \"white flashing waves of light\" is how I'd usually describe them. Nausea is very common during these periods hence the zofran. I had sleep apnea quite bad and finally got my bipap setup properly a bit over a month ago and now only have <1 to 3 events/hour so I doubt that's related anymore. I'm sleeping fairly well. The nicotine use is infrequent and not even daily. Sometimes I go months without it. I mentioned 1-3 pipes a day as that's my current use. Nicotine and caffeine excluded, the headaches remain. Days like today light bothers me a bit. High pitched sounds or constant sound are overwhelming. I'm not sure how mild migraines can be/if these headaches can be related but they remind me of a minor version of what I used to get. They start immediately when I wake and persist until I fall asleep. Usually on a high-fat keto diet for the epilepsy but no matter how I eat the headaches don't change. Whatever medications I am/am not on also don't seem to alter their behavior when this happens. It's wearing on me this time. Usually it's gone by a couple months but now I'm passing 3. Any input that I could then take back to my doctors would be greatly appreciated. Thank you in advance.
