It's possible that the seizures or the underlying cause of your epilepsy have affected areas of your brain responsible for energy regulation, motivation, or physical endurance.2. Weight Loss, Weight Gain, and EnergyMetabolic Changes: Rapid weight loss before your diagnosis might have stressed your body, and the subsequent weight gain could be related to changes in metabolism, medication side effects, or reduced physical activity. It's also possible that your body is struggling to adapt to these changes, which could contribute to your fatigue.Vicious Cycle: It's not uncommon for people to lose motivation to exercise when they feel physically unable to perform as they once did. This can lead to weight gain, which then makes exercise even harder, creating a cycle that's difficult to break.3. Autoimmune Disease and EpilepsyAutoimmune Epilepsy: There is growing recognition of autoimmune causes of epilepsy. Conditions like anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis, lupus, or Hashimoto's encephalopathy can cause seizures and are often accompanied by other symptoms like fatigue, brain fog, or systemic inflammation. If you suspect an autoimmune component, you could ask your doctor about testing for autoimmune markers or consulting a neurologist who specializes in autoimmune epilepsy.Leaky Gut and Inflammation: While the concept of leaky gut is still controversial in mainstream medicine, there is evidence that intestinal permeability and systemic inflammation can contribute to a range of health issues, including neurological conditions. If you're exploring this, consider working with a functional medicine practitioner or dietitian who can guide you through an elimination diet or other interventions to see if reducing inflammation improves your symptoms.4. Next StepsAdvocate for Yourself: If your current doctors aren't taking your concerns seriously, consider seeking a second opinion, especially from a neurologist who specializes in epilepsy or autoimmune conditions. You might also benefit from seeing an endocrinologist to rule out hormonal imbalances or metabolic issues.Track Your Symptoms: Keep a detailed journal of your energy levels, seizures, diet, exercise, and any other symptoms. This can help you identify patterns and provide concrete data to show your doctors.Explore Alternative Therapies: While not a replacement for medical treatment, therapies like acupuncture, yoga, or mindfulness practices might help with energy levels and stress management. Some people with epilepsy also find relief with ketogenic diets, which are worth discussing with your doctor.Mental Health Support: Dealing with chronic illness, weight changes, and the loss of your career can take a toll on your mental health. Consider talking to a therapist who specializes in chronic illness or joining a support group for people with epilepsy.5. Final ThoughtsIt's clear that you're motivated to understand what's happening to your body, and that's a great first step. While the medical system can be frustrating, don't give up on finding answers. Your experience is valid, and there may be underlying factors (like autoimmune issues or medication sensitivity) that haven't been fully explored yet. Keep advocating for yourself, and consider reaching out to specialists who might have a fresh perspective on your case.Let me know if you'd like help finding resources or crafting questions to ask your doctors. You're not alone in this, and there are people out there who can help you figure it out.

222.question: 25F - Last week I laughing gas at the dentist for the time, next day I had an episode with seizure-like movements, hyperventilating and was unable to move or speak. Ever since I’ve been experiencing “freezes” and difficulty processing. Waiting for neurologist appt.Last Tuesday, I had a filling done at the dentist and they gave me laughing gas the first time. It hit me pretty hard - I was given oxygen for 10 mins after and could still barely walk or talk. It took several hours for it to wear off. Wednesday morning, I felt completely fine. Around 1pm, I suddenly felt really bad - extremely nauseous, hot, and faint. Starting writing a simple email and just could not make sense of any of my thoughts or even string a sentence together - very strange feeling of nothing making sense, like I was in a dream. Had real difficulty moving my hands on the keyboard and could not coordinate my fingers to even type properly. My head kept falling back involuntarily. I was going to tell my boss I felt bad, next thing I know I’m sitting on the floor hyperventilating. According to my coworkers, I slammed my hands down on my desk and pushed myself backwards in my chair against the back of my cubicle, and was taking big loud gasping breaths as if I was choking. They helped me to the floor - I don’t remember this. They called 911 because they thought I was having a seizure. I was on the floor for 20 mins hyperventilating - I was aware of others around me but could not shift my gaze from the corner of the ceiling. I also could not move or talk. Paramedics came and took vitals and everything was fine apart from elevated heart rate. Went to the ER, they took bloods, EKG and head CT and all came back clear. Dr said it could be seizure but unlikely, or just a bad reaction to the laughing gas. He referred me to a neurologist for more testing. Basically every day since, I’ve had daily moments of “freezing” which last 10-20 secs. One time I was eating a sandwich, talking to my husband and my body just froze up and I was unable to speak and just felt completely blank and frozen - unable to speak and shift my gaze. Another time we were walking through target and my legs got really weak and locked up, and I felt an “aura” feeling, was unable to speak and just felt completely stuck and removed from reality. I’ve also noticed difficulty processing people talking to me - I’ve been having about 5 second “lags” which isn’t normal for me. Any idea what this could be? FYI no personal history of panic attacks or any anxiety, no family history of seizures, neurological issues etc.
222.answer: I'm not a doctor, but based on your description, your symptoms are concerning and warrant a thorough evaluation by a neurologist. Here are some possibilities that could explain your symptoms, though only a medical professional can provide a definitive diagnosis:1. Seizure or EpilepsyYour episode at work, with involuntary movements, hyperventilation, and post-episode confusion, could suggest a seizure. The freezing episodes you’ve been experiencing since then might be focal seizures (previously called partial seizures), which can cause brief lapses in awareness, staring, or involuntary movements without a full convulsive seizure.The aura you described (a strange feeling before an episode) is also common in seizures.Seizures can sometimes be triggered by stress, lack of sleep, or even certain medications or substances, including nitrous oxide (laughing gas).2. Reaction to Nitrous Oxide (Laughing Gas)Nitrous oxide is generally safe, but in rare cases, it can cause neurological side effects, especially if you have an underlying vitamin B12 deficiency. Nitrous oxide can inactivate vitamin B12, which is essential for nerve function. A severe deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms like numbness, weakness, confusion, and even seizures.If you have a history of poor diet, gastrointestinal issues, or other risk factors for B12 deficiency, this could be a contributing factor.3. Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) or StrokeWhile less likely given your age and normal CT scan, a TIA (mini-stroke) can cause sudden neurological symptoms like difficulty speaking, weakness, or confusion. However, these symptoms typically resolve within minutes to hours, and imaging would usually show evidence of a stroke.4. Migraine with AuraSome people experience migraine episodes with aura that can mimic seizures or strokes. These auras can include visual disturbances, confusion, difficulty speaking, or even weakness. However, migraines are usually accompanied by a headache, which you didn’t mention.5. Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures (PNES)These are episodes that resemble seizures but are not caused by abnormal electrical activity in the brain. They are often related to stress or psychological factors. However, given your lack of history with anxiety or panic attacks, this seems less likely.6. Other Neurological ConditionsConditions like multiple sclerosis (MS), encephalitis, or other brain disorders could cause similar symptoms, but these would typically show abnormalities on imaging or other tests.What You Should Do:See a Neurologist ASAP: Since you’re already scheduled, make sure to provide them with a detailed account of your symptoms, including the laughing gas exposure. They may recommend an EEG (to check for seizure activity), an MRI (to look for structural issues in the brain), and blood tests (to check for vitamin deficiencies or other metabolic issues).Mention Nitrous Oxide Exposure: Let the neurologist know about the laughing gas and how you felt afterward. They may want to check your vitamin B12 levels and consider whether the nitrous oxide could have played a role.Keep a Symptom Diary: Document every episode of freezing, including what you were doing, how long it lasted, and any triggers or patterns you notice. This will help the neurologist make a diagnosis.Avoid Driving or Risky Activities: Until you have a clear diagnosis and treatment plan, avoid activities that could put you or others at risk if you were to have another episode.Red Flags to Watch For:If you experience another episode lasting more than a few minutes.If you develop new symptoms like severe headache, weakness on one side of your body, or vision changes.If you feel increasingly confused or disoriented.Your symptoms are concerning, but the good news is that you’ve already had some initial tests (CT scan, EKG, blood work) that ruled out life-threatening causes like a stroke or heart issue. The next step is to work with the neurologist to get to the bottom of this. Hang in there, and don’t hesitate to seek emergency care if things worsen.

223.question: I suffered from this as a baby (parents said I almost died at birth and they had to put me in really cool environments and use ice at the hospital since I had low oxygen at birth. For a few weeks I was on some baby monitor ( I was also a c section) did a bit of searching online but couldn't find much discussion about this.About me currently Im a 28 year old Male 28M , the birth asphyxia obviously happened during birthAre there things happening during birth asphyxia that could leads to other issues? I suffer from ADHD or ADD which makes me wonder if this came from birth asphyxia and I have definitely had reactions to strong flashing lights when I was a teenager (still do a bit) i read that seizures could be a complication from birth asphyixia.
223.answer: Birth asphyxia, which occurs when a baby doesn’t receive enough oxygen before, during, or immediately after birth, can indeed have long-term effects depending on its severity and duration. While many children recover fully, others may experience complications that can affect their development and health later in life. Here’s how your history of birth asphyxia might relate to your current concerns:1. ADHD/ADD and Birth AsphyxiaThere is some evidence suggesting a link between birth complications, including asphyxia, and an increased risk of neurodevelopmental disorders like ADHD. Oxygen deprivation during birth can potentially affect brain development, particularly in areas responsible for attention, impulse control, and executive functioning. However, ADHD is a complex condition with genetic, environmental, and neurological factors, so it’s unlikely that birth asphyxia alone would be the sole cause.2. Sensitivity to Flashing LightsYour sensitivity to flashing lights could be related to a heightened neurological response, which might be influenced by your early brain development. Birth asphyxia can sometimes lead to subtle changes in brain function, including increased susceptibility to sensory stimuli. While this doesn’t necessarily mean you have a seizure disorder, it’s worth noting that:Photosensitivity (sensitivity to flashing lights) is a common feature of certain types of epilepsy, but it can also occur in people without epilepsy.If you’re concerned about seizures, it’s important to consult a neurologist. They can evaluate whether your symptoms are related to a seizure disorder or another neurological condition.3. Other Potential Long-Term Effects of Birth AsphyxiaCognitive and Learning Difficulties: Some individuals who experienced birth asphyxia may have mild cognitive impairments or learning difficulties, though this varies widely.Motor Impairments: In more severe cases, birth asphyxia can lead to conditions like cerebral palsy, which affects movement and coordination.Behavioral and Emotional Issues: There may be an increased risk of anxiety, mood disorders, or behavioral challenges, though these are often influenced by multiple factors.What You Can Do:Consult a Specialist: If you haven’t already, consider seeing a neurologist or developmental specialist to discuss your history and current symptoms. They can help determine if there’s a connection between your birth asphyxia and your ADHD or sensitivity to flashing lights.Neuropsychological Testing: This can provide insights into how your brain functions and whether there are any specific areas affected by your early experiences.Monitor Symptoms: Keep track of your reactions to flashing lights or any other unusual symptoms. If they worsen or interfere with your daily life, seek medical advice.Final Thoughts:While birth asphyxia can contribute to certain challenges, many people who experienced it go on to live healthy, fulfilling lives. Your ADHD and sensitivity to lights may or may not be directly linked to your birth experience, but understanding your history can help you and your healthcare providers make informed decisions about your care. If you’re curious or concerned, don’t hesitate to explore these issues further with a medical professional.

224.question: Age – 25 Sex – Male Height - 183cm 6ft Weight - 92kg 200lb Race – Caucasian Duration - Last 3 months Symptoms ive experienced over the last 3 months Around 2months ago i was experiencing Phantom smells, brief periods of 3-4second smells; started off as a blood smell and then startedto get them more frequently and smells were sometimes oranges/flowers. I Have since had an EEG that said i had no Temporal Lobe Epilepsy. I've not had these smells for a few weeks in the last 2 weeks i have started to notice eye floaters that follow where my eye goes only in sunlight. I have also noticed Bright flashing lights from the outter right corner of my eye. Some less worrying symptoms i have had. Sometimes 1 ear will get a high pitch noise that starts loud and fades out Muscle twitching hadaches sometimes. nothing severe Lightheadedness that may be related to anxiety/ or my low iron Sometimes cant think of the word i was thinking of or lose train of thought. Feel like im staring through what im looking at, kinda get daydreamy i guess? Also i do have a front tooth that is decaying / has a hole between the front and front right I have Severe anxiety and depression; and have been through a period of very high stress the last 3 months after breaking up with my long term partner. Is it possible that stress can do all these things to the body... my GP dosent seem worried about brain tumours but i am.
224.answer: I'm not a doctor, but I can provide some general information that might help you understand your symptoms. It's important to follow up with your healthcare provider for a proper evaluation and diagnosis.Possible Explanations for Your Symptoms:Phantom Smells (Olfactory Hallucinations):These can be caused by a variety of factors, including stress, anxiety, migraines, sinus issues, or neurological conditions. Since your EEG ruled out temporal lobe epilepsy, it’s less likely to be related to seizures, but other causes like stress or sinus problems could still be at play.Eye Floaters and Flashing Lights:Eye floaters are common and often harmless, especially in bright light. However, flashing lights can sometimes indicate retinal issues (e.g., retinal detachment or migraines). It’s worth seeing an ophthalmologist to rule out any serious eye conditions.Muscle Twitching, Headaches, and Lightheadedness:These symptoms can be linked to stress, anxiety, fatigue, or even nutritional deficiencies (e.g., low iron, magnesium, or vitamin B12). Stress and anxiety can also cause muscle tension, leading to headaches and twitching.Cognitive Symptoms (Word-finding difficulties, Daydreaming):Stress, anxiety, and depression can significantly impact concentration, memory, and cognitive function. This could explain why you’re experiencing difficulty focusing or losing your train of thought.Tooth Decay:Dental issues like a decaying tooth can sometimes cause referred pain or even systemic symptoms if left untreated. It’s important to address this with a dentist.Stress and Anxiety:Stress can absolutely cause or exacerbate a wide range of physical symptoms, including those you’ve described. Chronic stress can affect your nervous system, immune system, and overall health, leading to symptoms like muscle twitching, headaches, lightheadedness, and even phantom smells.Next Steps:Follow Up with Your GP: If you’re still concerned, ask your GP for further tests or referrals (e.g., to a neurologist or ophthalmologist) to rule out any underlying conditions.Address Stress and Anxiety: Consider therapy (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy) or stress management techniques (e.g., mindfulness, exercise) to help manage your anxiety and depression.Dental Care: See a dentist to address the decaying tooth, as this could be contributing to your overall discomfort.Nutritional Check: Ask your GP to check for deficiencies (e.g., iron, vitamin B12, magnesium) that could be contributing to your symptoms.Reassurance:While your symptoms are concerning to you, many of them can be explained by stress, anxiety, or other non-life-threatening conditions. It’s good that your GP isn’t overly worried about a brain tumor, but if your symptoms persist or worsen, don’t hesitate to seek a second opinion or further testing.Take care of your mental and physical health, and try to reduce stress where possible. You’re not alone in this, and many of these symptoms can improve with time and proper care.

225.question: Hello all, I had a question about my medication and fasting, if that's alright. I take Keppra twice a day (500mg each), once in the morning and once at night. With Ramadan approaching I was wondering how much time there needs to be in between taking one pill at night and one in the morning, thanks.Let me know if I need to add anything else.
225.answer: Hello! It's great that you're planning ahead for Ramadan while managing your medication. Keppra (levetiracetam) is an antiepileptic drug, and it's important to maintain consistent levels of it in your body to ensure its effectiveness. Typically, Keppra is taken every 12 hours to maintain stable blood levels, but your specific dosing schedule should be confirmed with your healthcare provider.During Ramadan, if you're fasting from dawn to sunset, you can adjust your dosing schedule to fit your eating and fasting times. For example:Night dose (after Iftar): Take your first dose after breaking your fast at sunset (Iftar).Morning dose (before Suhoor): Take your second dose before starting your fast at dawn (Suhoor).This way, you can maintain approximately a 12-hour interval between doses. However, the exact timing may vary depending on your location and the length of your fast. It's crucial to consult your doctor or pharmacist to ensure this adjusted schedule is safe and effective for you. They may also consider factors like your seizure control and overall health.If you experience any issues or have concerns, don't hesitate to reach out to your healthcare provider. Ramadan Mubarak in advance! Let me know if you have more questions.

226.question: Recently I got a hickie, and tons of people started telling me to be careful because I could die, and stuff. Is it that dangerous? Male 17, epilepsy, anxiety, question: are hickies dangerous?
226.answer: Hickeys, also known as love bites or kiss marks, are generally not dangerous. They occur when suction breaks small blood vessels under the skin, causing bruising. While they can look dramatic, they are usually harmless and heal on their own within a week or two.However, there are a few considerations to keep in mind, especially given your medical history:Epilepsy: If you have epilepsy, it's important to manage stress and avoid situations that could potentially trigger a seizure. While a hickey itself is unlikely to cause a seizure, the anxiety or stress from the situation might. Make sure you're following your treatment plan and taking any prescribed medications.Anxiety: If the attention or comments from others about the hickey are causing you significant anxiety, it's important to address this. Anxiety can be managed through various techniques such as deep breathing, mindfulness, or talking to a trusted friend or counselor.Rare Complications: In extremely rare cases, excessive suction on the neck could potentially lead to more serious issues, such as blood clots or damage to major blood vessels. However, this is highly unlikely from a typical hickey.Social Considerations: Hickeys can draw attention and comments, which might be uncomfortable for some people. If you're concerned about this, you can cover the hickey with clothing or makeup until it fades.In summary, hickeys are generally not dangerous, but it's important to manage any anxiety or stress they might cause, especially given your epilepsy. If you have any specific concerns or if the hickey is causing unusual symptoms (like severe pain or swelling), it's a good idea to consult with a healthcare professional.

227.question: 30 AFAB, 158cm/61kg, hispanic, Symptoms: lightheadedness, fatigue, darker urine, light periods. flu-ish [see below] since a month ago.Diagnoses: Epilepsy, ADHD, Endometriosis, 5cm ovarian cyst, migrainesMedications: Lamotrigine 225mg, Ibuprofen for endometriosis pain, very occasional Concerta, haven't used it for a few months, melatonin over the summer (stopped it about two months ago)Others: Drink 1-2 drinks monthly, Slowly stopping smoking down from 6 to 1-2 per day and 1 light snus, last two days have started taking Vitamin D and I have been using a therapy lamp for 20 min every morning for the last two weeks. Good, balanced diet and drink a lot of water. No drugs.Concerns: bad family history of cancer - quality of life affected.In Norway. What should I look out for to justify going to the doc? I would just live at the doctor's if I went every time something happens, especially since I have had several issues since I was a kid, but I also want to be mindful to not ignore things that might be important. I also tend to write off things as just depression/hormones, and once it was an iron deficiency, for instance. Thank you in advance!!   No idea what is related, so I will list things that have changed just in case, in order of concern. EELING FAINT/FATIGUE: I can't exercise much because I feel super lightheaded and I can't do some exercises now because I feel I am going to faint and I have had to cut down my training sessions. Thought I wasn't eating enough, but upped protein intake and started tracking calories and I am at maintenance level.  DEMOTIVATION: I want to be lying on the couch a lot even though it hasn't been typical of me. I am very demotivated, like nothing excites me and I can get a bit weepy (but I have had recurrent trouble with depression in the past so it might be that not being able to do much is making me lightly depressed...). I just moved to a nordic country, so thinking it might be related to the change into the autumn season, I am using a therapy lamp and started taking vitamin D. The lamp worked the first week. URINE: Every time I pee, it used to be clear because I drink so much water and now it is always very yellow no matter how much water I drink. LIGHT PERIOD: My period has become super light since last September, but the last 2-3 times I hardly have had it. I have taken a pregnancy test every 4 weeks just in case. All negative. I used to have 1 very, very heavy day changing tampon at least once an hour and some spotting after. A few years ago it was 3-4 of these very heavy days. OVARIAN PAIN: I have a 5cm cyst (found 10 years ago, grown from 2.5cm) that feels fuller and tender. It has been hurting me so much more than usual, cramping several times this last month and it hurts when I stretch or when I do certain exercises. I only mention this in case you know whether exercise or stretching can cause it to burst or twist the ovary to avoid it or in the off chance that it might be cancer related. I feel my hunger increased, but it might be unrelated, more nausea than usual. I have also been feeling like I am catching a flu constantly and I have already had what seems like a cold twice this month.
227.answer: Given your symptoms and medical history, there are several concerning signs that warrant a visit to a healthcare provider. Here’s a breakdown of what to look out for and why:1. Lightheadedness and Fatigue:Possible Causes: These symptoms could be related to a variety of issues, including anemia (iron deficiency), dehydration, hormonal imbalances, or even side effects from your medications (e.g., Lamotrigine). Given your history of iron deficiency, it’s important to rule this out again.Action: Consider getting blood tests to check for anemia, thyroid function, and electrolyte imbalances. Also, discuss with your doctor whether your Lamotrigine dosage needs adjustment.2. Dark Urine:Possible Causes: Dark urine can be a sign of dehydration, liver issues, or even a urinary tract infection (UTI). Given that you drink a lot of water, persistent dark urine is concerning.Action: A urine test can help rule out infections or other issues. Liver function tests might also be warranted.3. Light Periods:Possible Causes: Changes in menstrual flow can be due to hormonal imbalances, stress, or underlying conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or thyroid issues. Given your history of endometriosis and an ovarian cyst, this could also be related.Action: A pelvic ultrasound and hormonal panel (including thyroid hormones) could provide more insight.4. Ovarian Pain:Possible Causes: The increase in pain and tenderness around your ovarian cyst could indicate that the cyst has grown, changed, or is causing complications like torsion (twisting) or rupture. While exercise is unlikely to cause a cyst to burst, it can exacerbate pain if the cyst is already irritated.Action: A follow-up ultrasound is crucial to assess the cyst’s size and characteristics. If the pain becomes severe or sudden, seek immediate medical attention as this could indicate torsion or rupture, which are emergencies.5. Flu-like Symptoms and Frequent Colds:Possible Causes: Frequent colds and flu-like symptoms could indicate a weakened immune system, possibly due to stress, nutritional deficiencies, or an underlying condition.Action: Blood tests to check for immune function and nutritional deficiencies (like Vitamin D, B12, and iron) might be helpful.6. Demotivation and Mood Changes:Possible Causes: While this could be related to seasonal affective disorder (SAD) or depression, it’s also worth considering that physical health issues (like hormonal imbalances or chronic pain) can contribute to mood changes.Action: Continue using the therapy lamp and Vitamin D, but also discuss your mood changes with a healthcare provider to rule out underlying physical causes.When to See a Doctor:Immediately: If you experience severe abdominal pain, sudden changes in vision, or any signs of an ovarian cyst rupture (sharp, sudden pain, fever, nausea, vomiting), seek emergency care.Soon: Schedule an appointment with your doctor to discuss your symptoms, especially the lightheadedness, dark urine, and ovarian pain. Bring up your concerns about your family history of cancer and request appropriate screenings.Summary:Blood Tests: Check for anemia, thyroid function, liver function, and immune markers.Urine Test: Rule out infections or other issues.Pelvic Ultrasound: Assess the ovarian cyst and any changes.Hormonal Panel: Evaluate for hormonal imbalances affecting your periods and mood.Given your complex medical history and the interplay of symptoms, a thorough evaluation is essential to ensure that nothing serious is being overlooked. It’s better to be proactive, especially with a family history of cancer and the potential for serious complications from your ovarian cyst.

228.question: I’m (40F) 5ft 8, 164lbs, caucasian. Medications: Lamotrigine and Sertraline Health conditions: ADHD, Tourette’s, epilepsy and severe degenerative disc disease. I don’t have a current issue but every time I’ve had surgery I wake up completely full of beans, even when I’ve just woken up in recovery. I will stay hyper for hours afterwards and not feel surgical pain for the same amount of time. It can be quite funny, I talk at 100mph and can’t stop giggling. I don’t feel sick at all and always want water and food immediately. Drs/nurses etc have commented it’s like I didn’t even have surgery, but I’ve never asked if there’s a reason why. I’m not sure if it’s related but codeine does absolutely nothing for me and I always need extra anaesthetic at the dentist. I’ve never been told I’m difficult to put under GA. Thank you in advance, I’ve been wondering for years.
228.answer: Your experience of waking up from surgery feeling hyperactive, talkative, and pain-free is intriguing, and there are several factors that could contribute to this phenomenon. While I can’t provide a definitive diagnosis, I can offer some insights based on your medical history and the information you’ve shared:1. Medications and Neurological ConditionsLamotrigine and Sertraline: Both of these medications can influence your brain chemistry. Lamotrigine is an anticonvulsant used for epilepsy and mood stabilization, while sertraline is an SSRI used for depression and anxiety. These medications may affect how your body responds to anesthesia and pain management.ADHD and Tourette’s: These conditions involve dysregulation of neurotransmitters like dopamine, which could influence your response to anesthesia and post-surgical arousal. People with ADHD often have atypical responses to stimulants and sedatives, which might explain your heightened alertness after surgery.Epilepsy: Your history of epilepsy means your brain may process medications and anesthesia differently than someone without a seizure disorder. Anesthetic agents can sometimes have paradoxical effects in individuals with neurological conditions.2. Anesthesia and Pain ResponseResistance to Anesthesia: Your mention of needing extra anesthetic at the dentist and your high energy levels post-surgery suggest you may have a higher tolerance for certain anesthetic agents. This could be due to genetic factors, your neurological conditions, or even the medications you’re taking.Codeine Ineffectiveness: Codeine is a prodrug that needs to be metabolized into morphine to be effective. Some people (especially those with certain genetic variations in the CYP2D6 enzyme) don’t metabolize codeine well, rendering it ineffective. This could explain why codeine doesn’t work for you.Post-Surgical Euphoria: The combination of anesthesia, pain relief, and the stress of surgery can sometimes trigger a euphoric response in certain individuals. This might explain your giggling, talkativeness, and lack of pain immediately after surgery.3. Degenerative Disc Disease and Chronic PainYour history of severe degenerative disc disease means you may have a higher baseline tolerance for pain, which could contribute to why you don’t feel surgical pain immediately after the procedure. Chronic pain conditions can alter the way the brain processes acute pain signals.4. Possible Explanations for Your Post-Surgical BehaviorParadoxical Reaction to Anesthesia: Some individuals experience paradoxical reactions to sedatives or anesthesia, leading to hyperactivity or agitation instead of drowsiness.Adrenaline Surge: Surgery is a significant physiological stressor, and your body may release a surge of adrenaline as you wake up, contributing to your hyperactive state.Individual Variability: Everyone responds differently to anesthesia and surgery. Your unique combination of medications, health conditions, and genetics may simply make you more prone to this type of reaction.5. What You Can DoDiscuss with Your Anesthesiologist: Before any future surgeries, share this history with your anesthesiologist. They can tailor your anesthesia plan to account for your unique responses.Genetic Testing: If you’re curious about your resistance to codeine and anesthesia, you might consider genetic testing (e.g., for CYP2D6 enzyme activity) to better understand how your body metabolizes certain medications.Monitor and Report: Keep track of your reactions and share them with your healthcare providers. This information can help them optimize your care in the future.While your post-surgical behavior is unusual, it doesn’t seem to be harmful. However, it’s always a good idea to explore these reactions with your medical team to ensure they’re not indicative of an underlying issue. Your case is a great example of how individual variability can play a significant role in medical experiences!

229.question: 20 year old old Female. I’m taking 500mg of Keppra every morning for my epilepsy and I’ve been on it for about two years. I’ve just recently stopped taking amitriptyline 25mg about a week now. I’ve been going through the withdrawals but it’s been easing and the symptoms weren’t too bad besides the chills and shakes. I also take Ventolin inhalers for my asthma as well as paracetamols for migraines here and there. Anyway, I’ve had this sort of pain months ago. The stomach pain was unbearable and lasted a week or so until it soothed. It completely went away after a month or so. I think the annoying part was I constantly felt like I needed the bathroom. After the first day I didn’t actually need to use the bathroom but it just constantly felt like I did. It was very uncomfortable. I think eating made it worse but I can’t be too sure. I stopped drinking sodas or spicy foods and drank decaffeinated green tea with honey everyday. It went away and now suddenly it’s back. I’m also late with my period by 23 days but I usually have irregular periods. My stomach gurgles a lot too. If my stomach pain isn’t so bad it’s me needing to use the bathroom or my stomach making noises. My distress triggers anxiety attacks and that also doesn’t help.
229.answer: I'm sorry to hear you're dealing with this discomfort. Based on what you've described, your symptoms could be related to several potential causes, and it’s important to consider both gastrointestinal and hormonal factors, especially given your medical history and medications. Here are some possibilities to consider:1. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)Your symptoms (abdominal pain, bloating, feeling like you need to use the bathroom, and stomach gurgling) are consistent with IBS, a common functional gastrointestinal disorder.IBS can be triggered or worsened by stress, anxiety, or dietary factors (e.g., spicy foods, caffeine, or carbonated drinks).The fact that your symptoms improved with dietary changes (avoiding soda and spicy foods) and returned later suggests IBS could be a possibility.2. Medication Side Effects or WithdrawalKeppra (levetiracetam): While Keppra is generally well-tolerated, it can cause gastrointestinal side effects like abdominal pain or changes in bowel habits in some people.Amitriptyline withdrawal: Stopping amitriptyline can cause gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, abdominal discomfort) as part of withdrawal, though these usually resolve within a few weeks.Paracetamol (acetaminophen): Overuse of paracetamol can irritate the stomach lining, but this is less likely if you’re only taking it occasionally for migraines.3. Hormonal InfluencesYour delayed period and irregular cycles could be linked to hormonal fluctuations, which might also affect your gastrointestinal system. For example, progesterone levels can cause bloating, cramping, and changes in bowel habits.Stress and anxiety (which you mentioned) can disrupt your menstrual cycle and exacerbate gastrointestinal symptoms.4. Food Intolerances or SensitivitiesCertain foods (e.g., dairy, gluten, or high-FODMAP foods) might trigger abdominal pain, bloating, or the sensation of needing to use the bathroom.Keeping a food diary to track what you eat and how you feel afterward could help identify potential triggers.5. Other Gastrointestinal ConditionsGastritis or Peptic Ulcers: These can cause stomach pain, especially after eating.Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO): This can cause bloating, gurgling, and changes in bowel habits.Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD): Conditions like Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis can cause abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits, but these are usually accompanied by other symptoms like blood in the stool or weight loss.What You Can Do:Dietary Adjustments:Continue avoiding spicy foods, sodas, and caffeine.Consider trying a low-FODMAP diet (under the guidance of a dietitian) to see if it helps.Stay hydrated and eat smaller, more frequent meals to reduce strain on your digestive system.Stress Management:Since stress and anxiety seem to worsen your symptoms, try relaxation techniques like deep breathing, meditation, or yoga.If anxiety attacks are frequent, consider speaking with a therapist or your doctor about additional support.Track Your Symptoms:Keep a diary of your symptoms, diet, and menstrual cycle to identify patterns or triggers.Medical Evaluation:If the pain persists or worsens, consult your doctor. They may recommend tests like:Blood tests (to check for inflammation, infections, or hormonal imbalances).Stool tests (to rule out infections or malabsorption).Imaging (e.g., ultrasound or endoscopy) if needed.When to Seek Immediate Medical Attention:If you experience severe pain, fever, vomiting, blood in your stool, or unexplained weight loss, seek medical care promptly, as these could indicate a more serious condition.It’s great that you’ve already made some dietary changes and are mindful of your symptoms. However, since this is a recurring issue, it’s worth discussing with your doctor to rule out any underlying conditions and ensure your treatment plan is optimized. Take care!

230.question: Gender: Female, Age: 9, Height: Idk tbh, Location: Head, How long ago: 1 week.So my co-workers daughter was just diagnosed with grey matter heterotopia. She was crying her eyes out today, and I felt really bad. She brings her daughter to work quite often and we love her here. She is a wonderful kid, and we were all really sad with the news. I was hoping to shed a little bit of light, maybe some information on what their options are. They have to wait until October for their doctor to talk to them about the subject while her daughter still has seizures and her parents just suffer. I wanted to brighten up her day, and even if the news are bad or there aren’t many options... at least I wanna give her some clarity. Any and all responses are welcomed.Thank you!
230.answer: I'm so sorry to hear about your co-worker's daughter. It's understandable that this is a very difficult time for her and her family. Grey matter heterotopia (GMH) is a neurological condition where clusters of grey matter (brain cells) are located in the wrong part of the brain, often due to a disruption during fetal development. It can cause seizures, developmental delays, and other neurological symptoms, but the severity varies widely from person to person.Here’s some information that might help provide clarity and hope:What is Grey Matter Heterotopia?GMH is a type of neuronal migration disorder, meaning the brain cells didn’t move to the correct location during early brain development.It’s often diagnosed when someone has seizures or developmental delays, as in your co-worker’s daughter’s case.The condition can be isolated or associated with other genetic or developmental conditions.What Are the Options?While I’m not a doctor, here are some general options that are often considered for managing GMH:Medication for Seizures:Anti-seizure medications (anticonvulsants) are typically the first line of treatment. Many people with GMH respond well to medication and can achieve good seizure control.If one medication doesn’t work, doctors may try others or combinations of medications.Monitoring and Support:Regular follow-ups with a neurologist are important to monitor seizures, development, and overall health.Early intervention programs (speech therapy, occupational therapy, etc.) can help address developmental delays if they arise.Surgical Options (in some cases):If seizures are not controlled with medication and are significantly impacting quality of life, surgery might be considered. This could involve removing or disconnecting the abnormal brain tissue causing the seizures.However, surgery is only an option if the heterotopia is in a location that can be safely accessed.Genetic Testing:In some cases, genetic testing may be recommended to determine if the GMH is linked to a specific genetic condition. This can help guide treatment and provide information about the prognosis.Lifestyle and Support:A healthy lifestyle, including proper sleep, stress management, and avoiding seizure triggers, can help manage symptoms.Support groups for families dealing with epilepsy or neurological disorders can provide emotional support and practical advice.What Can You Do to Help?Offer Emotional Support: Your co-worker is likely feeling overwhelmed. Simply being there to listen and offer comfort can mean a lot.Share Reliable Resources: Point her to reputable organizations like the Epilepsy Foundation (epilepsy.com) or Child Neurology Foundation (childneurologyfoundation.org) for more information and support.Help Brighten Their Day: Small gestures, like bringing her a coffee, offering to help with tasks, or even sharing a funny story, can make a big difference during a tough time.Reasons for HopeMany children with GMH lead full, happy lives with proper treatment and support.Advances in neurology and epilepsy treatment mean there are more options than ever before.Early diagnosis and intervention can improve outcomes.It’s great that you’re looking for ways to support your co-worker and her daughter. Even if the news feels overwhelming, knowing they have a supportive community around them can make a huge difference. Let them know they’re not alone, and encourage them to take things one step at a time. Wishing them all the best as they navigate this journey.

231.question: 25F, 200lb, 5’4, asthma, current medications wellbutrin SR, vyvanse, lexapro, montelukast, spironolactone. i do not drink any alcohol, use cannabis 5-7x a weekOccasionally, I will have an intense sensation of deja vu, followed by a sensation that I can only describe as disoriented. It’s almost like a combination of intense nausea, dizziness, and confusion, which will be very intense for a few seconds before dissipating. After the initial peak, I will feel “weird” for anywhere between 10 mins to a half hour afterwards, sometimes I will be nauseous for awhile, sometimes I will need to lay down, sometimes I feel too overwhelmed to socialize, etc. (I do sometimes experience deja vu WITHOUT the weird sensations too, just the general feeling of unease that comes with a cognitively dissonant experience like deja vu.)This used to happen a lot more as a kid, and stopped for awhile, but recently it’s happened once or twice and made me wonder why it happens. When I was younger I think I used to be able to “control” whether it progressed if I caught the sensation early enough? For example, if I started having that “I’ve been here before” feeling, if I leaned into it and tried to figure out if it was a dream, what came next, etc, the strange feelings would come on; occasionally if I tried to move on from the topic it would just stop at the deja vu and leave me just a little bit weirded out by the experience.I do tend to remember my dreams very vividly, and I have read online that people who do tend to be more susceptible to deja vu. Occasionally I can even tell when I have the sensation and am in fact experiencing the set-up to a dream (i.e opening a closet and then waiting for the “next scene” so to speak from the dream). I am just curious if this is normal, if these weird feelings are just part of deja vu or if it’s something else?
231.answer: The sensations you're describing—intense déjà vu followed by disorientation, nausea, dizziness, and confusion—are not typical of ordinary déjà vu and could potentially be related to a neurological phenomenon. Given your medical history (asthma, medications, and cannabis use) and the specific nature of these episodes, it’s worth considering a few possibilities:1. Temporal Lobe Epilepsy (TLE) or Focal SeizuresThe symptoms you describe (déjà vu, disorientation, nausea, dizziness, and confusion) are classic features of focal aware seizures (previously called simple partial seizures), which often originate in the temporal lobe. These seizures can occur without loss of consciousness and may be followed by a postictal period (the weird feeling afterward).Temporal lobe epilepsy is often associated with vivid dreams, déjà vu, and intense emotional or sensory experiences.The fact that you could sometimes control the progression of these sensations as a child might suggest a neurological origin, as some people with focal seizures report being able to interrupt or modify their experience during the aura phase.Next Steps:Consider discussing these symptoms with a neurologist. They may recommend an electroencephalogram (EEG) to check for abnormal electrical activity in the brain, particularly in the temporal lobe.Keeping a detailed diary of these episodes (frequency, triggers, duration, and symptoms) can help with diagnosis.2. Medication Side Effects or InteractionsYour current medications (Wellbutrin SR, Vyvanse, Lexapro, montelukast, and spironolactone) are generally well-tolerated, but some can cause dizziness, confusion, or neurological symptoms in certain individuals.Wellbutrin (bupropion): Can lower the seizure threshold, especially in individuals with a predisposition to seizures.Vyvanse (lisdexamfetamine): A stimulant that can cause dizziness, confusion, or anxiety in some people.Lexapro (escitalopram): Rarely, SSRIs can cause neurological symptoms like dizziness or confusion.Cannabis use: While cannabis is not typically associated with seizures, it can cause derealization, dizziness, or disorientation in some individuals, especially with frequent use.Next Steps:Review your medications and cannabis use with your prescribing doctor or psychiatrist to rule out any potential interactions or side effects.3. Derealization or DepersonalizationThe sensations you describe (feeling weird, disoriented, or overwhelmed) could also align with derealization (feeling detached from your surroundings) or depersonalization (feeling detached from yourself). These can occur due to anxiety, stress, or even as a side effect of medications or cannabis use.However, the intense déjà vu and the specific progression of symptoms make this less likely as the primary explanation.4. Migraine with AuraSome people experience neurological symptoms (e.g., déjà vu, dizziness, confusion, or nausea) as part of a migraine aura, even without a headache. These symptoms can last for minutes to hours and may be followed by a postdrome phase (feeling off afterward).Next Steps:If you have a history of migraines or other migraine-like symptoms (e.g., visual disturbances, sensitivity to light or sound), this could be worth exploring with a doctor.5. Psychological FactorsStress, anxiety, or trauma can sometimes manifest as physical or neurological symptoms, including déjà vu, dizziness, or disorientation. However, the episodic and stereotyped nature of your symptoms suggests a more physiological cause.Recommendations:Consult a Neurologist: Given the episodic and stereotyped nature of your symptoms, a neurological evaluation is important to rule out focal seizures or other brain-related issues.Keep a Symptom Diary: Document the frequency, triggers, duration, and specifics of each episode to help your doctor identify patterns.Review Medications and Cannabis Use: Discuss your current medications and cannabis use with your doctor to rule out any potential contributors.Consider an EEG or MRI: If your doctor suspects seizures or another neurological condition, they may recommend imaging or an EEG to assess brain activity.Final Thoughts:While déjà vu is a common experience, the additional symptoms you describe (disorientation, nausea, dizziness, and confusion) are not typical and warrant further investigation. Temporal lobe epilepsy or focal seizures are a strong possibility, but other causes (e.g., medication side effects, migraines) should also be explored. It’s great that you’re paying attention to these symptoms—early evaluation can help identify the cause and ensure appropriate management.

232.question: ’m a 60yr old fit male with Gerd due to a Hiatal hernia. Have been on PPIs for 22 years. Have had a history of passing out on occasion after weight lifting/working out. Doctors did cardio tests /tilt table with no results for explanation. One neurologist said I had epilepsy another one said absolutely not. No one seemed to take into account the PPI and Gerd condition and that this only happened after work outs. Could the weight lifting be affecting the Vagus nerve and causing the light headedness and the seizure like passing out episodes?
232.answer: It's possible that your symptoms could be related to your GERD, hiatal hernia, or even the long-term use of PPIs, though the connection isn't entirely straightforward. Let’s break this down:1. Hiatal Hernia and GERDA hiatal hernia can irritate the vagus nerve, which runs near the diaphragm and esophagus. The vagus nerve plays a key role in regulating heart rate, blood pressure, and digestion.Weightlifting or intense exercise can increase intra-abdominal pressure, which might exacerbate a hiatal hernia and potentially stimulate the vagus nerve. This could lead to a phenomenon called vasovagal syncope, where the vagus nerve overreacts, causing a sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure, leading to lightheadedness or fainting.2. Vagus Nerve and ExerciseThe vagus nerve can be sensitive to mechanical pressure or irritation, especially during activities like weightlifting that increase abdominal pressure. This could trigger a vasovagal response, causing dizziness or fainting.Additionally, straining during heavy lifting can cause a temporary reduction in blood flow to the brain (similar to the Valsalva maneuver), which might contribute to lightheadedness or passing out.3. PPIs and Potential Side EffectsLong-term PPI use has been associated with certain side effects, including magnesium deficiency (hypomagnesemia), which can cause muscle weakness, irregular heart rhythms, and even seizures in severe cases. Low magnesium levels could theoretically contribute to your symptoms, especially after exercise when electrolyte imbalances might be more pronounced.PPIs can also affect nutrient absorption (e.g., vitamin B12, iron), which could indirectly contribute to fatigue or neurological symptoms.4. Seizure-like EpisodesIf your episodes involve loss of consciousness with jerking movements, it’s possible they could be mistaken for seizures. However, vasovagal syncope can sometimes cause brief convulsive movements, which might be confused with epilepsy.The fact that these episodes occur specifically after workouts suggests a potential link to physical exertion rather than a primary neurological condition like epilepsy.5. Next StepsReevaluate GERD and Hiatal Hernia: Discuss with your gastroenterologist whether your hiatal hernia could be contributing to vagus nerve irritation, especially during exercise. They might recommend further imaging or tests to assess the hernia’s size and impact.Electrolyte and Nutrient Levels: Ask your doctor to check your magnesium, calcium, potassium, and vitamin B12 levels, as deficiencies could contribute to your symptoms.Monitor Exercise Intensity: Consider modifying your workout routine to avoid excessive straining or heavy lifting. Focus on exercises that don’t dramatically increase intra-abdominal pressure.Vagus Nerve Evaluation: If vasovagal syncope is suspected, a cardiologist or neurologist might recommend additional tests, such as a Valsalva maneuver test or autonomic nervous system evaluation.6. Lifestyle AdjustmentsAvoid heavy meals before working out, as this can increase intra-abdominal pressure and exacerbate GERD.Stay hydrated and ensure adequate electrolyte intake, especially if you sweat heavily during exercise.Consider working with a physical therapist or trainer to adjust your weightlifting technique to minimize strain on your diaphragm and abdomen.ConclusionWhile the exact cause of your episodes isn’t clear, the connection to exercise and your history of GERD and hiatal hernia suggests that vagus nerve irritation or vasovagal syncope could be playing a role. It’s worth exploring this possibility further with your healthcare team, particularly focusing on the interplay between your hernia, GERD, and exercise.

233.question: 29F, height 165cm, weight 74kg, caucasian. I do not smoke or have regular dairy. Weekly alcohol consumption would be 2-7 standard drinks per week at most.  also regularly have lean meat and 3 veg for lunch and dinner and a fruit smoothie for breakfast. Current diagnoses: epilepsy, mild chronic pancreatitis Regular medications are: AM: 500mg Kepra, vitamins D+magnesium PM: 500mg Kepra, vitamin D+magnesium I am awaiting follow-up with a gastroenterologist about why my pancreas could be nibbling on itself (lypase has been found to be between 70-100 on multiple occasions). I have a history of treating my anxiety with alcohol and fast food but over the last 8 years or so (since my early 20's) I've gone to therapy and gotten it really well under control. I never had these symptoms before when I had unhealthy habits but over the last year my pancreas has not been having a good time. Every month or 2 I get these very specific pains that I now know is mild chronic pancreatitis. It's never brought on by a change in routine, it's always random.
233.answer: It sounds like you're managing several health conditions, including epilepsy and mild chronic pancreatitis, while maintaining a generally healthy lifestyle. Here are some key points and considerations based on the information you've provided:1. Chronic PancreatitisSymptoms: The recurring pain you describe is consistent with chronic pancreatitis. The randomness of the pain episodes, despite a stable routine, suggests that the condition may be influenced by factors other than diet or lifestyle, such as underlying anatomical or metabolic issues.Lipase Levels: Elevated lipase levels (70-100 U/L) indicate pancreatic inflammation. While your levels are not extremely high, they are above the normal range (typically 10-60 U/L), which warrants further investigation.Follow-Up: It’s good that you’re awaiting a follow-up with a gastroenterologist. They may recommend additional tests, such as imaging (CT, MRI, or endoscopic ultrasound) to assess the structure of your pancreas and rule out other causes like gallstones, autoimmune pancreatitis, or genetic factors.2. Epilepsy and MedicationsKeppra (Levetiracetam): You’re on a standard dose of Keppra, which is effective for managing epilepsy. Ensure you stay consistent with your medication, as missed doses can increase the risk of seizures.Vitamin D and Magnesium: These supplements are beneficial, especially since vitamin D deficiency is common and magnesium can help with nerve function and muscle relaxation. However, excessive magnesium can sometimes cause gastrointestinal issues, so ensure you’re not exceeding recommended doses.3. Diet and LifestyleAlcohol: Your current alcohol intake (2-7 standard drinks per week) is relatively low, but even moderate alcohol consumption can exacerbate pancreatitis. Consider reducing or eliminating alcohol entirely to see if it improves your symptoms.Diet: Your diet sounds balanced, with lean meat, vegetables, and fruit smoothies. However, for pancreatitis, a low-fat diet is often recommended to reduce the workload on the pancreas. You might consider reducing fat intake further and focusing on easily digestible foods.Hydration: Ensure you’re staying well-hydrated, as dehydration can worsen pancreatic issues.4. Anxiety and Mental HealthIt’s great that you’ve made significant progress in managing your anxiety through therapy. Stress and anxiety can indirectly affect physical health, so continuing to prioritize mental health is important.5. Next StepsGastroenterologist Consultation: Be prepared to discuss your symptoms, diet, alcohol intake, and any family history of pancreatic or gastrointestinal issues. They may order additional tests or suggest dietary modifications.Pain Management: If the pain becomes more frequent or severe, ask your doctor about safe pain management options that won’t interfere with your epilepsy or pancreatitis.Monitor Symptoms: Keep a symptom diary to track pain episodes, diet, alcohol intake, and any potential triggers. This can help identify patterns and guide treatment.6. Potential Red FlagsIf you experience severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or jaundice (yellowing of the skin or eyes), seek immediate medical attention, as these could indicate a more serious pancreatic issue.Overall, you’re taking many positive steps to manage your health. The upcoming gastroenterologist appointment should provide more clarity and help tailor a plan to address your pancreatitis. In the meantime, continue to prioritize a healthy lifestyle and avoid potential triggers like alcohol and high-fat foods.
